Title: Military Advice Services Framework
Description:
Advice and analysis in relation to the subject matter of contracts to which the Defence Reform Act 2014 applies. Military advice services will include providing strategic advice and analysis on military related topics. These services will require significant knowledge of the defence industry, both in the UK and worldwide. Areas of support and advice required may include but are not restricted to:
a) Qualitative analysis capabilities including experience to assist in understanding procurement and manufacture, such as: 
i) technical understanding on what is being procured and the associated risks;
ii) operational knowledge of aspects of the Front Line Commands and the MOD and the uses of the equipment in question;
iii) practical application of military knowledge in weapons and equipment; and
iv) understanding of the manufacture methods of specific equipment types.
b) Quantitative analysis of risk in a defence industry context, including its application to the cost risk adjustment as part of the SSRO’s profit rate methodology.
Attachments: Military Advice Services Framework - Statement of conduct.docx Military Advice Services Framework - ITT.docx Military Advice Services Framework - Pricing Schedule.docx Military Advice Services Framework - Brief.docx Military Advice Services Framework - Terms and Conditions.docx Military Advice Services Framework - Response to clarification questions.docx Military Advice Services Framework - Form of Tender.docx Military Advice Services Framework - Responses to questions.docx

Title: United Kingdom-Telford: Military vehicles and associated parts
Description: 'Military vehicles and associated parts. The Authority is considering establishing an Enabling Contract (EC) for spares in support of MOWAG Duro and Light Weight Trailer used by the British Army. The duration of the EC shall be firm for 2 years with the option to extend for a further year. The requirement shall consist of a range of items and the Authority is seeking a single supplier to provide all items, which are available from a range of original equipment manufacturers. Tenderer's shall be provided with NATO Stock Numbers and using ISIS, shall be required to source and price the items in scope for the requirement. There are no drawings or specifications available to issue with the Invitation to Tender. The Authority reserves the right to add items of a similar nature to the contract during its lifetime. It is the Authority's intention to operate electronic trading by migrating the Contract to Purchase to Payment (P2P) from the onset. Any resulting contract shall contain a set of Key Performance Indicators to measure performance in areas such as delivery and quality and shall include remidies for poor performance. Expressions of Interest are to be submitted via the Dynamic PQQ which can be accessed using the access code provided in this advert. In accordance with the Government's transparency agenda, the Authority shall publish the Tender and Contract documents online. Further guidance shall be provided in the ITT.'

Title: CCDT/598 Advanced Military Fan Systems
Description: Published for transparency purposed only. DO NOT APPLY. The Defence Equipment and Support (DE&S), Future Capabilities Group has placed a circa 4.5 year, single sourced contract under the directive and funding of the Future Combat Air Systems Technology initiative, for the development and demonstration of an Advanced Military Aerospace Fan Systems (AMFS) Technology and Capability Concept Demonstrator, with Rolls-Royce Plc, (RR). The contract seeks to complement, complete and extend extant research and development carried out by RR under previous programmes and will focus on the development, experimentation, analysis and enhancement of Aircraft Vertical Lift and propulsion systems; their design and manufacturing technologies, air-vehicle integration and potential to increase aircraft performance and capability, whilst reducing through life costs.

orgName: Ministry of Defence, Land Equipment, Other
Title: Provision of whole aircraft charter for the transportation of military and government cargo and personnel worldwide
Description:
The Authority has a requirement for whole aircraft charter for the transportation of military cargo and personnel worldwide. The Authority requires the ability to access commercial aircrafts in order to augment its military fleet in times of operational surge or to transport exceptional loads. Suppliers are required to provide flexible access to the commercial whole aircraft charter market in a dynamic and fast moving military environment.
      
      The requirement has been split into four Lots:
      Lot 1 - Cargo 
      Lot 2 -Cargo Emergency
      Lot 3 - Passenger
      Lot 4 - Passenger Compassionate
      
      There is no limit to the number of Lots a supplier may apply to tender for. Suppliers may apply for one Lot only (except Lot 2) or for more than one Lot.  In order to apply for Lot 2 - Cargo Emergency, suppliers must successfully apply for Lot 1 Cargo. Suppliers cannot apply for Lot 2 only. 
      
      Framework Agreements will be awarded for each Lot.
Additional Text:

        http://www.contracts.mod.uk/delta/signup.html?userType=supplier
        
        and search for the notice with reference 'UK-Bristol: Non-scheduled air transport services.'.

orgName: Ministry of Defence, Air Support, Air Commodities Project Team (AC PT)
Title: Provision of Engineering and Logistic Support to Aircraft Arrestor Systems in use in the UK and at overseas military bases - RHAG and PAAG
Description:
Repair, maintenance and associated services related to aircraft and other equipment. Aircraft-operation services. The Air Commodities Team has a requirement to procure a Support Solution for the provision of engineering support of Aircraft Arrestor Systems in use across the UK and Overseas at military air bases.

The UK MOD currently utilises a fleet of 18 Air Transportable deployable Portable Aircraft Arresting Gear (PAAG) P-IV/BAK-12 and 30 installed Rotary Hydraulic Arrestor Gear (RHAG Mk1) Model 44B-3A Water Twister Energy Absorption systems from Engineered Arresting Systems Corporation (ESCO) as the Original Equipment Manufacturer.

These systems fulfil the subject capability for MOD Main Operating Bases (MOB), Permanent Joint Operating Bases (PJOB) and overseas Deployed Operating Bases (DOB) which operate Fixed Wing Training and Fast Jet military aircraft. 

A spares inclusive availability based support contract is required for 10 years to provide engineering support including but not limited to;
refurbishment & repair of major assemblies, 
Post Design Services, 
RHAG & PAAG tapes,
Pendant cable assemblies.

Title: Transforming the D-Day Museum - Military Vehicle Conservation Specialist
Description:
Portsmouth City Council 'the Council' is inviting quotes from suitably qualified professional practices to provide specialist military vehicle conservation services for the Transforming the D-Day Museum Project. 
      
      The collection consists of the following vehicles: 
      
      ? LCVP 1993/32 
      ? BARV (Beach Armoured Recovery Vehicle) 1990/1403 
      ? Sherman Tank 1990/1400 
      ? Churchill Crocodile Tank 1990/1405 
      ? DUKW Amphibious Vehicle 1990/1402
      ? 25 pounder field gun 2003/2517
      
      A specialist vehicle or military vehicle conservator with an appropriate conservation qualification is required to undertake the removal, transport, conservation and storage of all or some of the vehicles on display at the D-Day Museum.
Additional Text:
Portsmouth City Council is currently in the process of seeking expressions of interest for the following project - Transforming the D-Day Museum - Military Vehicle Conservation Specialist

Title: Provision of Equine Dentistry Services to Military Working Horses
Description:
To provide routine and advanced dental care to circa 400 military working horses of the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment and The Kings Troop Royal Horse Artillery.

Visits are to be made at regular intervals through the year to each unit as follows:

a.	HCMR   - 7 visits treating up to 33 horses per visit 
b.	HCTW   - 2 visits treating up to 33 horses per visit
c.	KTHRA  - 5 visits treating up to 25 horses per visit

In addition, one visit a year to the Royal Military Academy Sandhurst, Camberley, Surrey, GU15 4PQ is required to treat up to 8 horses.

The Authority is considering placing a 16 month Enabling Contract (with options for  a further 3 years).

Title: The Provision of a Verbatim Court Recording Service to the Military Court Services (MCS)
Description: The Authority requirement is for the provision of a Verbatim Court Recorder’s (VCR) service at all Service Court proceedings in the Court Martial, the Service Civilian Court and the Summary Appeal Court for the Army, Royal Air Force and Royal Navy (including Royal Marines). The service is also required to cover judicial hearings, Army Board Oral Hearings (OH) and Service Inquiries (SI) convened by the Army.  These proceedings, hearings and inquiries are predominantly held at the 5 permanent Military Court Centres (MCCs), four of which are located in the United Kingdom (at  Bulford, Colchester, Catterick and Portsmouth) and the fifth at Sennelager in Germany. The principal requirement is for VCRs in UK and Germany, but there is also potentially a requirement to support Court proceedings, hearings and inquiries on a global basis. For instance, in recent years occasional proceedings have been held in Cyprus, Brunei, Belize, Gibraltar, Canada, Kosovo, the Falkland Islands and USA.

Title: GB-Andover: Provision of a Witness Support Service to the military Court Service (MCS)
Description:
The Authority has a requirement for the management and provision and management of specially trained witness support volunteers to attend service courts to provide support and practical assistance to prosecution and defence witnesses, both military and civilian involved in service court proceedings, predominately in the UK but occasionally in other locations.  All personnel must be trained to National Standards, as recognised by the Home Office.  The requirement is expected to commence from 01 September 2016 and expire on 31 August 2018 with a built in option period for a further one year period or part thereof.  
This requirement is being advertised under the 'Open Procedure' and therefore, not seeking expressions of interest.  If your organisation is interested in tendering for the requirement you will need to gain access to the 'Supporting Documentation' which contains the Invitation to (ITT) documentation under access code:9P4N7C8K5Q. Full details of how to apply and complete the ITT are contained within the DEFFORM 47 - Special Notice to Tenderers.
Contact Address 1: Army HQ Branch, IDL 437, Floor 2, Zone 8, Ramillies Building,

Description:
Babcock DSG Limited acting on behalf of the Authority has under consideration a 5 year Framework Agreement for the supply of military parts and associated items which includes but is not limited to the following NSN's.  The Authority may add items of a similar nature to the Framework Agreement if required during the contract period.

      This requirement will be split into lots.  Suppliers who progress to the Invitation to Tender Stage can bid for one lot, several lots or combination of lots.  A framework agreement covering all lots or framework agreements for individual or combination of lots will be awarded based upon the lowest priced combination for all lots over the 5 year contract period.
      
      Tenderers shall be provided with NATO Stock Numbers and manufacturers' part numbers and, using ISIS, shall be required to source and price the items in scope for the requirement. 
      
      
      Expressions of Interest to participate in this requirement are to be submitted on the DCO by completing the DPQQ.  The DPQQ shall be assessed on the DCO using the selection criteria given within the DPQQ and within each question.  Only those suppliers who provide all mandatory information and are not subject to a mandatory exclusion will be invited to tender.  
      
      The following code is required to access the DPQQ - U775F9437R.

orgName: Ministry of Defence, Helicopters, Apache Project Team
Title: HELSS/0090 - Procurement of Cockpit Situational Awareness Tool  (CSAT) for UK Military Helicopters.
Description:
Procurement of a Commercial Off The Shelf (COTS) Cockpit Situational Awareness Tool(CSAT) System for UK Military Helicopters.  This procurement will cover the acquisition and support for the system.  This system shall comprise of Portable Electronic Device and mission planning  hardware/software and shall be operated by aircrew (note;not integrated into the aircraft) and will use approved MOD data, referenced by GPS.     The product required must:
      a) Be capable of receiving foundation Geospatial Intelligence (GOEINT) MOD data,
      b) Provide optimised battery life
      c) Be capable of effective operation in flight by aircrew
      d) Be available as a trial model at least Technical Readiness Level 7* for aircraft evaluation (Ground and Flight) to support risk reduction of  wire strike and vertical obstacles collision avoidance 
      e) Provide a data validation function
      *Technical Readiness Level 7 is defined by the European Commissions as "System Prototype demonstration in operational environment.
Additional Text:
To view this notice, register as a supplier here:
        
        http://www.contracts.mod.uk/delta/signup.html?userType=supplier
        
        and search for the notice with reference 'UK-Yeovil: Digital mapping system.'.

Title: The Supply of Forage to Military Working Horses
Description:
The Authority has a requirement for the supply of equine processed wood bedding (Lot 1), equine processed cardboard bedding (Lot 2), straw, roughage and produce (Lot 3), feed (Lot 4) and supplements (Lot 5) for the period 1 May 2018 for 3 years with an option for one further year, for Military Working Horses in various locations as detailed in each statement of requirement.
      Contractors must be able to deliver goods within 48 hours of an order being received to the required location. For guidance only, Contractors might be required to make up to 3 deliveries per week during normal working hours ie. 0800 - 1600 hours during weekdays. This may rise during periods of increased tempo of operations. Deliveries may also be requested over a weekend to meet ceremonial, regimental show or operational commitments.

Title: Future Service Delivery Contract (FSDC): Provision of Armed Forces Pay, Pensions and Military HR and Administrative Services
Description:
The proposed FSDC will cover the Armed Forces and Veterans Defence Business Services (DBS) services that are currently outsourced, which at a high level consist of:
      
      a.	A variety of personnel support services for the Royal Navy, Army and Royal Air Force, in the form of Joint Personnel Administration (JPA), which is the MOD's current Military Payroll and Expenses HR system, and Pensions; and
      b.	The development and maintenance of a range of supporting Information System (IS) applications and elements of IS infrastructure.
      
      This FSDC contract will:
      a.	Enable the radical transformation and modernisation of these services; 
      b.	Continually develop change management and ways of working; and
      c.	Potentially expand the current contract scope by including services currently carried out in house by Defence.
      
      A detailed Service Requirement Document (SRD) and Data Room has been developed and will be issued to those potential providers who are successful at the Pre-Qualification Questionnaire (PQQ) stage as part of the Invitation To Negotiate (ITN) documentation.

Title: Provision of Services to Support the Randomised Controlled Trial of Military Hip Rehabilitation Outcome (MILO)
Description:
3.	The aim of this project is to provide statistically robust data for comparison of residential rehabilitation versus conventional physiotherapy lead outpatient care in the management of non-arthritic hip pain to determine if cumulative mechanical loading of the hip constitutes a real occupational risk for non-arthritic hip pain in military personnel. This will be achieved by:

a.	Recruitment of Research Assistant to:
i.	support participant recruitment, screening and data collection (RA).
ii.	support database maintenance and subsequent data analyses (RA).
b.	Scientific scrutiny of the methods of data collection, analysis and interpretation by Principle Investigator.

Title: Provision of Light Arcraft for the Delivery of Military Parachute raining and RAF Falcons Activity
Description: Provision of UK based Light Aircraft for the Delivery of Military Parachute Training (MPT) and RAF Falcons Parachute Activity (FPA) to include parachute displays to the public. The contract duration will be 3 core years plus 2 one-year options for MPT and 3 core years for FPA, the proposed Contract start date is 1 July 2020.

Title: Future Service Delivery Contract (FSDC): Provision of Armed Forces Pay, Pensions and Military HR and Administrative Services
Description:
The FSDC will cover the Armed Forces and Veterans Defence Business Services (DBS) services that are currently outsourced, which at a high level consist of:
      
      a.	A variety of personnel support services for the Royal Navy, Army and Royal Air Force, in the form of Joint Personnel Administration (JPA), which is the MOD's current Military Payroll and Expenses HR system, and Pensions; and
      b.	The development and maintenance of a range of supporting Information System (IS) applications and elements of IS infrastructure.
      
      This FSDC contract will:
      a.	Deliver the services in scope; 
      b.     Enable the radical transformation and modernisation of these services; and 
      c.	Continually develop change management and ways of working;

Title: Provision of air transport for military passengers and passengers from other Government Departments.
Description:
NOTE: This notice was updated on 03 November 2015 for the following reason: 
Dates to be corrected in the original notice:
Place of dates to be added: IV.3.4
Instead of: 23 November 2015 Time: 12:00
Read: 23 November 2015 Time: 12:00
Other additional information: The contracting authority considers that this contract may be suitable for economic operators that are small or medium enterprises (SMEs). However, any selection of tenderers will be based solely on the criteria set out for the procurement, and the contract will be awarded on the basis of the most economically advantageous tender.Suppliers interested in working with the Ministry of Defence should register on the MOD Supplier Information Database (SID) Register, available at www.contracts.mod.uk.  The MOD SID is a database of active and potential suppliers available to all MOD and UK Defence procurement personnel, and is the main supplier database of MOD Procurement organisations. Please note: the registration and publication of a company profile on the MOD SID does not mean or imply that the supplier has in any way been vetted or approved by the MOD. Suppliers wishing to compete for advertised MOD contracts must respond to any specific call for competition by submitting a separate expression of interest in accordance with the instructions of the purchasing organisation.

From 2 April 2014 the Government is introducing its new Government Security Classifications Policy (GSC) to replace the current Government Protective Marking Scheme.  A key aspect of this is the reduction in the number of security classifications used.  All suppliers to the Department are encouraged to make themselves aware of the changes as it may impact on this Requirement.  The link below to the Gov.uk website provides information on the new GSC. 

 https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/government-security-classifications 

 The Authority reserves the right to amend any condition related to security of information to reflect any changes in national law or government policy.  If any contract documents are accompanied by instructions on safeguarding classified information (e.g. a Security Aspects Letter), the Authority reserves the right to amend the terms of these instructions to reflect any changes in national law or government policy, whether in respect of the applicable protective marking scheme, specific protective markings given, the aspects to which any protective marking applies, or otherwise. 

Advertising Regime OJEU:- This contract opportunity is published in the Official Journal of the European Union (OJEU),the MoD Defence Contracts Bulletin and www.contracts.mod.uk
Provision of whole aircraft commercial passenger charter in support of MOD operations, exercises and compassionate travel worldwide.
The MOD will reserve its right to use other contracts to meet its requirements as necessary.
Additional Text:
To view this notice, register as a supplier here:

http://www.contracts.mod.uk/delta/signup.html?userType=supplier

and search for the notice with reference 'UK-Bristol: Non-scheduled air transport services.'.

Title: Transportation and Installation oh Military Heritage Vehicles

One object will be required for display in April 2019 and will require removal of the first object and installation of the second in October 2019 and relocation of a third object in Apr 2020.

Title: AWARDED CONTACT - Provision of Temporary Stabling for Military Working Horses
Description:
Temporary stabling required on hire as and when demanded by The Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment  (HCMR) and The Kings Troop Royal Horse Artillery (KTRHA), primarily for their annual summer camps and for the occasional State Visit. Potential quantities required are as follows: HCMR - up to 196 single stalls plus 12 double tack units; KTRHA - up to 108 stables plus other units for veterinary use and storage of kit and equipment. Full details are provided in the Statement of Requirements as part of the Invitation to Tender document.

orgName: Ministry of Defence, Combat Air, UK Military Flying Training System (UKMFTS) Project Team
Title: Air Support to Defence Operational Training (ASDOT)
Description:
Text to be corrected in the original notice:
Place of text to be modified: II.7
Instead of: II.7)Additional Information:
         ASDOT is a Category ‘A’ programme and under current planning assumptions may be delivered in incremental phases – Phase one will be introduced from 2020 for 15 years and the estimated value is approximately £750 Million. Phase two could add another £300M-500M over the remaining 8 years. 
Description of Procurement
The scope of the ASDOT programme currently covers provision of live flying assets to meet the following training requirements:-
• Air to Air Combat
• Air to Surface Combat
• Joint Terminal Attack Controller (JTAC)/Forward Air Controller (Airborne) (FAC(A))
• Electronic Warfare
• Air Traffic Control (ATC), Ground Based Air Defence (GBAD) and Aerospace Battle Management (ABM)
• Live Gunnery
The ASDOT team is currently working towards an Investment Decision by the end of 2016. Under current plans, a competition for this requirement under the Negotiated Procedure will be launched with the release of a Pre-Qualification Questionnaire (PQQ). At this time it is envisaged that a single 15 year contract will be let covering the delivery of the requirement through a phased approach. It is important to the Authority that as many interested parties be given the opportunity to understand and consider ASDOT ahead of formal engagement and therefore an Industry Day is planned, at a date to be advised, this will be an opportunity for potential suppliers to learn more about the requirement document.
Some Industry engagement has already taken place during the Concept Phase through the Niteworks Partnership and the Authority now invites companies wishing to learn more about this requirement or offer views on contract duration, phasing and performance measures, technology insertion points and capability enhancements, to contact the Project Team which would be happy to engage.
This PIN is to alert the market to this potential future requirement and is NOT a formal request for Expressions of Interest (EOI). A Contract Notice and Dynamic PQQ may be issued at a date after the Industry Day to request EOIs which shall reference this PIN. 
Enquiries should be sent by email to: DESUKMFTS-ASDOT-Cmrcl-Industry@mod.uk
Read: II.7)Additional Information:
         ASDOT is a Category ‘A’ programme and under current planning assumptions may be delivered in incremental phases – Phase one will be introduced from 2020 for 15 years and the estimated value is approximately £750 Million. Phase two could add another £300M-500M over the remaining 8 years. 
Description of Procurement
The scope of the ASDOT programme currently covers provision of live flying assets to meet the following training requirements:-
• Air to Air Combat
• Air to Surface Combat
• Joint Terminal Attack Controller (JTAC)/Forward Air Controller (Airborne) (FAC(A))
• Electronic Warfare
• Air Traffic Control (ATC), Ground Based Air Defence (GBAD) and Aerospace

Title: Professional OPFOR (Project HANNIBAL)
Description:
Training services. Specialist training services. Training services in defence and security materials. Project HANNIBAL.  A training support project predominantly, but not exclusively, focused in the LAND environment, supporting collective training.  HANNIBAL will deliver improvements to the design, planning, delivery and control of Command Post Exercises (CPXs) in the constructive domain, while also providing analysis and mentorship of training audience activity.  The collaborative solution, working with Army planning and training teams, will provide a permanent exercise control (EXCON), mainly based in Warminster but deployable across several training estates, to better deliver and control exercises using the Decisive Action Training Environment (DATE).  Fundamental to the service, is the provision of a permanent peer plus opposing force (OPFOR), mainly based in Warminster and supported by computer operators (Pucksters) operating at reach, using virtual/simulated networks.  The OPFOR, supported by deployable subject matter expert (SME) role players (White Cell) will replicate the full spectrum of current and emerging threats to consistently test the training audience to the threshold of failure.  Critically, HANNIBAL is committed to continuously improving the delivery of CPXs to ensure the training audience is able to maximise the learning opportunity from these critical events.   
      
      HANNIBAL Support to training includes, but is not limited to:
      a.   The constructive environment to best represent the complexities and frictions of contemporary warfare and ensure the training audience is fully tested.  
      
      b.   Representative forces ranging from allied through neutral and indigenous to opposing, such as military, paramilitary, police, Opposition Force (OPFOR) and represent bodies across the full spectrum of the given scenario nationalities/geographical environment (government officials, military, civilians etc). 
      
      c.   Training Support. Design and plan CPXs in support of military training teams through the provision of key posts in the military led EXCON and design cell.  
      
      d.  Training Support.  Support and inform the observations from training process to ensure CPXs continuously improve and help identify lessons from training.
      
      e.   Training Delivery. Support the military training team in the delivery of CPXs through the provision of key posts in EXCON.

Title: GB-Glasgow: Understanding Defence Audiences - Discovery Phase
Description:
NOTE: This notice was updated on 21 August 2015 for the following reason: Reduce number of characters within the description to allow publishThe Ministry of Defence need to gain insight into the behaviour, needs and context of the varied audiences across the whole of UK Defence Personnel. At this stage we aim to get a baseline understanding that can be iteratively improved upon in the future. 
There are approx 250,000 civilian and military personnel within Defence across geographically dispersed locations and multiple organisations as well as military personnel within Defence - regular and reserve (not just the single services and taking into consideration 2 year role rotation): 
-	HOCS (Head Office and Corporate Services)
-	Royal Navy
-	British Army
-	Royal Air Force 
-	DE&S (Defence Equipment and Support)
-	DIO (Defence Infrastructure Organisation)
-	DSTL (Defence Science and Technology Laboratory) 
-	DBS (Defence Business Services)
-	JFC (Joint Force Command) 
-	UKHO (UK Hydrographic Office)
-	DSG (Defence Support Group) 

Within and across each organisation there are a wide variety of people in terms of experience, working environments, access to technology, needs and knowledge, behaviours. 
Insight will come from interrogating & analysing both the data MOD already has available & that gathered during this process. However, data is in different locations and will require mining from systems such as HRMS for civilians and JPA for military personnel. This suggests a very wide stakeholder community that needs to be engaged.
This project comes in the midst of a cultural shift in how technology is used, with a major overhaul and rolling out of Office 365 across Defence Personnel. Personas have been created for the New Style of IT programme which covers:
-	Role activities and responsibilities  
-	Mobility of personnel 
-	Levels of collaboration required within roles
-	Levels of use and type of information based activity
-	Pain points 
-	Device needs 
These elements are detailed for the following types of role that are representative within and across Defence:
-	Senior Leaders  
-	Line Managers
-	Information Workers
-	Office Enablers
-	Responders 
-	(Military) Trainees 
-	Reservists 
-	Field Workers
-	(Technical) Specialists
-	Contractors 
-	Industrial Partners
-	MOD External
-	Deployed Personnel
-	Personnel in Barracks  

Objectives
Gathering data from across UK Defence Personnel enhance the existing Personas covering:
-	Vital statistics
-	Who they are – life cycle and career cycle
-	Experience and beliefs 
-	General attitudes to work and Defence 
-	Behaviour – what they do 
-	Needs (functional, informational and emotional)
-	Passion points (both positive and negative)
Additional Text:
To view this notice, register as a supplier here:

http://www.contracts.mod.uk/delta/signup.html?userType=supplier

and search for the notice with reference 'GB-Glasgow: Understanding Defence Audiences - Discovery Phase'.

Title: Aviation Support for British Forces Brunei
Description: Provision of Aviation Support Service for British Forces Brunei for the capability to deploy, retrieve and supply exercising troops in a jungle environment and deployment for Humanitarian Aid and Disaster Relief. The Service is to include a medical evacuation capability for casualties, by means of winching, and a stretcher if necessary, accompanied by a Military medic, from point of injury to an appropriate Medical Treatment Facility. The Service will be provided through a Military Registered Civil Owned aircraft solution which will be operated by Military pilots. To provide a support solution that will be compliant with Military Airworthiness Authority regulations. The Service will be utilised for 1200 flying hours over 320 days per year, for 5 years, in all weather conditions within the operating limits of the aircraft, crew and local aviation rules. The approximate contract length is 6 years including transition to service to meet a delivery date of 1 Oct 2017.

orgName: Ministry of Defence, Land Equipment, Operational Support Programmes (OSP)
Title: SUPPLY AND SUPPORT OF A LIGHT PROTECTED MOBILITY RECOVERY (LPMR) VEHICLE.
Description:
Armoured military vehicles. Repair and maintenance services of military vehicles. The provision and in-service support (including but not limited to spares, repairs, PDS and ad-hoc tasking) Protected Mobility (PM) vehicles of a modern design for UK Armed Forces. 

LPMR will support the rapidly deployable forces (i.e. first-in, airborne or amphibious capability) as well as the regular armed forces. LPMR must therefore provide protected mobility against real world scenarios encountered by military forces conducting Global Operations.

As a core equipment, LPMR shall have an in-service life of at least 25 years.  
In order to achieve a Planning Assumption for Service Entry (PASE) date during 2019, the LPMR capability is expected to be based on Military off the Shelf (MOTS) mature platforms of modern design. 

Whilst a detailed system requirements document will be released as part of the Invitation to Negotiate (ITN), the following should be considered as general characteristics of a vehicle suitable to meet the LPMR requirement.

OCCUPANTS 
•   1 x Driver 
•   1 x Commander 

CAPACITY
•   LPMR must be fitted with a winch (minimum capacity 10,000 kg).
•   LPMR must be able to undertake suspend/support towing activities (minimum lift capacity 4000 kg)
•   LPMR must have an ability to stow and transport its Complete Equipment Schedule (CES) items.

DIMENSIONS
•   Max width 2500mm
•   Max Height 2650mm (transit mode)

TRANSPORTABILITY
•   LPMR must be capable of being transported by land, sea and air (including but not limited to A400M and C17) with minimal preparation. There is no requirement to transport under slung by rotary wing aircraft.

MOBILITY
•   LPMR shall have ≥ Improved Medium Mobility load carrying classification. 

SURVIVABILITY
•   To provide Threshold protection to the occupants from ballistic threat at ≥ Stanag Level 2 and blast threat at ≥ Stanag Level 2.

Title: SBRI Challenge - Non Destructive Evaluation (NDE)
Description:
Develop an NDE technique with capacitive resitivity imaging (CRI) technology providing the capability to map variations of bulk low-frequency electrical properties within a structure and sensitive to any defects (e.g. cracks and fractures) or alterations (e.g. corrosion) affecting either electrical resistivity or dielectric properties of a material.
Develop the NDE technique in the following areas of military exploitation:
• In-situ evaluation of structural materials covered by sheathing, cladding, panelling, paint, tiles, flooring, insulating blankets, spray-on sealants or similar;
• Detection and monitoring of moisture and/or increased salinity in structural or building materials;
• Detection and monitoring of thermal anomalies in structural materials (without direct contact).
The work is to be undertaken in accordance with the SBRI application 59098-446144 submitted and held by Innovate UK for the Non-Destructive Evaluation programme. Key deliverables are:
1. Proof of concept that CRI technology is transferable from earth science and can deliver tangible benefits for military NDE; (20/11/2015)
2. A design concept for a highly portable and rapidly deployable CRI sensor array and instrumentation, suitable for in-situ military NDE; (07/12/2015)
3. A pioneering and systematic assessment (predictive simulation and experimental lab study using geophysical benchtop prototype instrumentation) of the CRI response to representative material flaws, reflecting those commonly encountered in military assets; (08/01/2016)
4. A detailed technical report including de-risking activities, rationale for design decisions, emerging characteristics of a likely commercial prototype, and details of route to market; (02/05/2016)

orgName: Liverpool City Region L E P
Title: Development of an evolutionary study, director plan and management plan that is centred on the range of industrial and maritime heritage assets located along Liverpool's iconic waterfront
Description:
The Local Enterprise Partnership is one of nine partners participating in the Military, Maritime and Industrial Atlantic Heritage Project.  The project is funded through the European Development Fund (ERDF) and runs to June 2020.  

This tender specification sets out the key deliverables for the development of an evolutionary study, director plan and management plan that is centred on the range of industrial and maritime heritage assets located along Liverpool's iconic waterfront.  It also sets out the scope of requirements for the delivery of the final plans and specifies the timescales within which the activity must be completed.

The Military, Maritime and Industrial Atlantic Heritage Project (MMIAH) is funded through the Interreg Atlantic Area ERDF programme and will run for three years and commenced in July 2017.  The project has nine city partners from the UK, Northern Ireland, France, Republic of Ireland, Spain and Portugal.  

The specific objectives of the project are focused on the recovery and rehabilitation of abandoned military or industrial heritage sites relating to the sea for tourism and the benefit of local communities.  Comprising 7 work programmes, the project will fund a programme of research and development activity to establish those sites that offer the greatest potential in this regard.  It will also support the creation of operational and maintenance plans for each city that will help support the detailed development of the assets that have been prioritised.

Through a range of pilot intervention plans, the initiative will also support projects in agreed locations that will encourage local resident engagement in local military, maritime and industrial heritage (MMI), as well as repurposing them for tourism.  Finally the project seeks to develop best practice for the development of MMI and at its conclusion, will have established a joint use-planning model and management model that can be transferred and implemented in other cities.
Attachments: TENDER BRIEF - Interreg WP4  WP5 23080818 (003).docx Appendix A - WP4 Methodology for the analisys and evolutionary study.odt Copy of Appendix B - MMI Inventory.xlsx Appendix C - Examples of Good Practice Liverpool LEP.pdf

Title: Airport Operational Database Management System
Description:
Newquay Cornwall Airport has a requirement to replace its airport operational management system.
Newquay Cornwall Airport (IATA:  NQY, ICAO: EGHQ) is the main commercial Airport for Cornwall and is located 4 NM (7.4 km; 4.6 mi) northeast of Newquay on Cornwall's north coast.  Newquay Cornwall Airport was previously a military base formerly known as RAF St. Mawgan before the transition from military to civilian status in December 2008.
The land where Newquay Cornwall Airport is situated is owned by Cornwall Council and controlled by Cornwall Airport Limited (CAL), a wholly owned subsidiary of Cornwall Council.  Due to the airports geographical position within the UK, the airport acts as a significant gateway to and from Cornwall for both the business and tourism sector. In relation to business, the airport offers daily connections to destinations across the UK that may not be achievable by other transport means within the same day. The airport handles over 20,000 movements covering schedule, military, training and business and general aviation traffic.

orgName: Ministry of Defence, Land Equipment, Operational Infrastructure Programme (OIP)
Title: Post Design Services for Logistics Support Bridge
Description:
•	Brief Outline
o	Contractual in-service support in the form of Design Authority (DA) Post Design Services (PDS) and Technical Support (TS) for Logistic Support Bridge (LSB)
o	The specially developed military components include rapid build, highly adjustable variable slope ramp systems; special ground beam assemblies and heavier transverse beam sections to cater for the heaviest military loads. The LSB can be configured to carry loads up to Military Load Class (MLC) 80T and MLC 110W and to cater for a wide variety of civilian loads including vehicles with low ground clearance. The standard decking finish of the LSB is a ‘Durbar’ chequer plate finish that enables tracked vehicles to cross without causing damage.
o	The primary mission of the LSB is for use on Main Supply Routes to upgrade these for heavier traffic, replace damaged civilian bridges, release assault and general support bridges and to provide a long span floating bridge capability.
o	Tasking may involve the consideration of proposals to incorporate changes for new requirements into the System and also the effect of these proposed changes on other equipments. 

•	Contract info (Length and type)
o	A requirement for a new three year contract, from 01 Sep 2016 to 31 Aug 2019, with two one year extension options to 31 Aug 2020 and 31 Aug 2021 respectively.
Additional Text:

and search for the notice with reference 'UK-Bristol: Technical support services.'.

Title: GB-Bristol: SBRI Challenge - Non Destructive Evaluation
Description:
Develop an NDE technique with capacitive resitivity imaging (CRI) technology providing the capability to map variations of bulk low-frequency electrical properties within a structure and sensitive to any defects (e.g. cracks and fractures) or alterations (e.g. corrosion) affecting either electrical resistivity or dielectric properties of a material.
Develop the NDE technique in the following areas of military exploitation:
• In-situ evaluation of structural materials covered by sheathing, cladding, panelling, paint, tiles, flooring, insulating blankets, spray-on sealants or similar;
• Detection and monitoring of moisture and/or increased salinity in structural or building materials;
• Detection and monitoring of thermal anomalies in structural materials (without direct contact).
The work is to be undertaken in accordance with the SBRI application 59098-446144 submitted and held by Innovate UK for the Non-Destructive Evaluation programme. Key deliverables are:
1. Proof of concept that CRI technology is transferable from earth science and can deliver tangible benefits for military NDE; (20/11/2015)
2. A design concept for a highly portable and rapidly deployable CRI sensor array and instrumentation, suitable for in-situ military NDE; (07/12/2015)

Title: Supply of Chest Seals
Description:
The current chest seal used is the Russell Chest Seal. Leidos is looking to procure a Chest Seal which has
undergone the same UK military operational testing as the Russell Chest Seal. The introduction of a Chest
Seal that doesn't meet the required UK Military operational testing could prove a potential risk to life.
Justification for naming a brand within a requirement is covered within PCR 2015 at Section 5,
Technical Specifications, 42 - (5) Required characteristics may include testing and test methods and (12)
technical specification to refer to a specific make or source is justified by the subject matter of the contract.
Leidos expect the Russell Chest Seal to be the only suitable product. However, if a supplier was to present
an equivalent Chest Seal which has undertaken and passed the specified UK Military operational testing
requirements and also meets the Leidos requirement, Leidos is prepared to consider such as an alternative
Additional Text:
For further detail please see OJEU notice at the above link, reference 2016/S 227-414087

to respond to the tender please register on the Leidos Supply Portal as per the above link.

Title: Provision of Upkeep Management Services for the CSS Team
Description:
The Commercially Supported Shipping (CSS) Boats team has a requirement for the provision of upkeep management services in respect of programmed upkeeps/refits and repairs for the following vessels, including but not limited to:
P2000 (Archer Class) Boats - HM Ships Archer, Biter, Blazer, Charger, Dasher, Example, Exploit, Explorer, Express, Pursuer, Puncher, Raider, Ranger, Smiter, Tracker, Trumpeter

Fast Patrol Vessels (FPV) HM Ships Sabre and Scimitar

Training Ships HMS Bristol, Sir Tristram, Brecon and Hindostan

Survey Boat HMS Gleaner

Ocean Survey Ship HMS SCOTT

Other boats, less than 50 metres in length

This requirement will also include the provision of overseeing services for military equipment fits on Royal Fleet Auxiliary (RFA) vessels.

Tasks to be carried out shall include, but not be limited to:
For all Vessels excluding RFAs:
The Contractor shall provide overseeing services (as and when tasked by the Authority) at the premises of the Contract Ship Repairer (CSR) or User location at any United Kingdom (UK) site or overseas, during the period of the upkeep or repair period. Tasks and responsibilities shall include, but not be limited to, the following:

Ensuring that the CSR delivers all that is required by this contract.

Ensuring that only Essential Tasks are added to the CSR’s contract.

For RFA Vessels only:
The Contractor shall, as and when tasked by the Authority, oversee the repair, overhaul, refitting and upgrading of all military equipment fits during Upkeep Periods, ensuring that the Contract Ship Repairer (CSR) complies with all relevant military and Classification regulations and standards.

Additionally:
The Contractor may be required to provide assistance to the Authority in the writing of upkeep specifications.

How to Register on the CCS eSourcing Suite

Full details of this opportunity can be found on the e-sourcing portal please follow instructions below. If you have not yet registered on the eSourcing Suite, this can be done online at https://gpsesourcing.cabinetoffice.gov.uk by following the link 'Register for CCS eSourcing'.

Your email must clearly state: 
•	name and reference for the procurement you wish to register for; 
•	name of the registered Bidder;

Crown Commercial Service will process the email and then enable the Bidder to access the procurement online via the e-Sourcing Suite. The registered user will receive a notification email to alert them once this has been done. The Sourcing documents can then be accessed on the eSourcing Suite at: https://gpsesourcing.cabinetoffice.gov.uk using the instructions detailed in the Specification documents within Contracts Finder.

Title: Indian Army Memorial  Room Redisplay
Description:
The National Army Museum wishes to appoint an Art Handling/installation and transport contractor for a two-phase de-install and install of paintings in the Indian Army Memorial Room (IAMR) at Royal Military Academy Sandhurst including some transportation to/from our store in Stevenage. 

Scope of Works:
Phase 1 (see Annex A)

•	To de-install 16 paintings and plaques from IAMR, pack and transport to NAM Store, Stevenage. We will provide 1 travel frame; all others can be soft wrapped.

•	To de-install 16 paintings currently hanging in the corridor leading to IAMR, soft-wrap and return to NAM Store, Stevenage.

•	To de-install 16 paintings currently hanging in IAMR, soft-wrap 14 and pack into modules (to be provided by contractor) and pack 2 into travel frames which will be provided by the museum. 

•	To deinstall 3 paintings currently hanging in the corridor leading to IAMR, soft-wrap and pack into modules (to be provided by the contractor) and then re-hang in IAMR as part of phase 2. 

•	To soft-wrap 1 large painting in-situ to remain on the wall in IAMR. 

Phase 2
•	To pack and transport up to 55 framed oil paintings (see attached list - Annex B) from NAM Store, Stevenage to Royal Military Academy Sandhurst. 4 travel frames to be provided by the contractor, remaining works to be softwrapped.

•	To pack and transport other 3D objects (see attached list - Annex C) from NAM Store, Stevenage to Royal Military Academy Sandhurst. Approximately 5 large crates to be provided by the contractor. 

•	To install 74 paintings to a pre-agreed hanging plan at various heights up to 7 metres in the IAMR (55 works on Annex B + 19 works from Annex A).

•	After install, return empty travel frames and packing to NAM Store, Stevenage.
Attachments: NAM IAMR Sandhurst brief for painting hang 20190617 FINAL.docx Annex A - oils at Sandhurst.pdf Annex B - oils at Stevenage.pdf Annex C - objects.pdf

Title: Supply and Support of Pre Hospital Emergency Care (PHEC) Ultrasound Devices - RFI
Description:
*Please review the  attachment for a detailed description. *

BACKGROUND

In April 15 the MOD signed a contract with Leidos Europe Ltd to provide the procurement and inventory management of commodity items (as well as the storage and distribution services) historically provided in-house by the Logistic Commodities and Services Operating Centre. Leidos, working with the MOD, will transform the way these services are delivered to ensure requirements continue to be met whilst providing best value for money for the department. The organisation delivering these services is known as Team Leidos.

FUTURE ARRANGEMENTS

Further to our Request for Information (RFI - first issued 22.08.2019) for Diagnostic Ultrasound Devices (DUS - reference LSL/MED/0063), Military Radiology Specialists within both the Emergency and Secondary Health Care environments have expressed an interest in seeing a broader range of devices as part of our upcoming Industry Day. 

The Industry Day has been scheduled to take place on the 17th October 2019 at the address listed below. Please contact Team Leidos for booking confirmation using the following details:

Contact person: Konstantin Nikolov
Telephone: +44 117 332 8575 
E-mail: Konstantin.Nikolov100@teamleidos.mod.uk

Industry Day Information - Thursday 17th October 2019

Address 
RAF Brize Norton
Main Gate 
OX18 3LX.

Arrival Time 
From 08:00 - Suppliers will be required to check in with Security at the Main Gate and obtain a pass before being directed to allocated parking.  

Duration
The event is scheduled to start at 10:00 and finish at 15:00. 

An exact itinerary for the day including updated running times, and information required in advance for access to site, will be provided to confirmed attendees closer to the event. 

UPDATE FOLLOWING RFI RELEASED 22.08.2019

Team Leidos' original intention was to plan an Industry Day to reflect the requirement for DUS devices only (for use in Regional Rehabilitation Centres). Whilst there have been no changes to the DUS requirement (Ref-LSL/MED/0063 - referenced within the PIN issued 08.08.2019 or subsequent RFI released 22.08.2019), the scope of the Industry Day has widened to include viewing a broader range of devices. 

To this end we would like to invite suppliers to showcase devices with the capability to provide Pre Hospital Emergency Care (PHEC) within a range of military environments. It's our intention to furnish a wider audience of Military Radiology Specialists with enhanced industry knowledge, to help with the development of future projects. 

The results and analysis of this RFI shall not constitute any form of pre-qualification exercise and any formal procurement process will be undertaken in accordance with EU Procurement Law.
Nothing in this RFI, or any other engagements with Industry prior to a formal procurement process, shall be construed as a representation as to Leidos' ultimate decision in relation to the future requirement.
Attachments: Pre Hospital Emergency Care (PHEC) Ultrasound Devices- RFI (Final).DOCX

Title: GB-Bristol: Manufacture of Puma MK2 Aircraft Covers
Description:
Manufacture of Puma MK2 Aircraft Covers

The Puma Gazelle Project Team has a requirement to place a three year contract (with a potential option to extend for a further year) for Puma HC Mk2 Environmental Aircraft Covers. The covers should be breathable but water proof and close fitting. The covers shall come with a warranty for at least 4 years against humidity and UV damage and the design of the covers should reflect the need to fit the covers in potentially poor weather conditions. The design solution should protect the aircraft in temperatures down to -30°C and up to +50°C and the technical abilities of the materials and fastenings should remain as advertised within this temperature range. The covers must protect from snow, ice, dust and sand, be suitable for military use, being of a rugged construction and will be required to be sand coloured. The covers should be abrasion resistant and tear resistant and the solution shall come with bags to store the covers.  

The Puma Gazelle Project Teams requirement includes a mixture of daily use covers, primary covers and secondary covers. Daily use covers protect the cockpit and nose of the aircraft, (not including the forward mounted DAS and equipment below this area) and the engines (including the PIPS). Primary covers protect the cockpit, nose and equipment on the nose, the engines (and PIPS), the main rotor head, the main rotor blades, the tail rotor head and the tail rotor blades. Secondary covers protect the tail fin, the tail boom, the main gearbox up to the main rotor head, the IR jammer, the wheels and sponsons and the stabiliser.

The supplier will be able to demonstrate that they will be able to design the covers to fit around components that are not currently embodied on the aircraft, (locations and dimensions will be provided). Examples of these components include but are not limited to a Wire Strike Protection System (WSPS), Aircraft Collision Avoidance System (ACAS), antennas and dehumidifier access. Additionally the supplier will be able to demonstrate that they can provide the skills and techniques to measure the aircraft accurately ensuring the suitability of the covers for use including fit, anchoring and safety. Finally the provider shall be competent; having demonstrable experience of supplying covers for rotary winged aircraft, preferably in a military setting and shalll have at least two positive references from previous customers.

The supplier shall be required to measure the aircraft themselves (at a date to be announced) to establish the fit of the covers. The Puma Gazelle Project Team will also give advice to build in capability to fit parts not yet on the aircraft.

In your response to this advert please provide a statement to support the above.
Additional Text: The contracting authority considers that this contract may be suitable for economic operators that are small or medium enterprises (SMEs). However, any selection of tenderers will be based solely on the criteria set out for the procurement, and the contract will be awarded on the basis of the most economically advantageous tender.

Title: Materiel Strategy - Managed Service Provider - Work Package 1 - Project Delivery - Fleet
Description:
Background

The UK MOD's Defence Equipment and Support (DE&S) organisation has a requirement to appoint a number of Managed Service Providers (MSPs) to transform and improve the operation of its project delivery. For this requirement project delivery is used to describe the totality of the products and services that DE&S delivers to MOD, be it procuring new military equipment, commodities and services, supporting in-service equipment through-life or managing global logistics operations.
This requirement is part of the DE&S's wider Materiel Strategy change programme. Under the change programme, the DE&S organisation has been established as a Bespoke Central Government Trading Entity within the public sector from 01/04/14, with new management freedoms and controls that are appropriate to its challenges and the specialist nature of its business.

Requirement

The Work Package is split into four contracts covering project delivery of each of the four Domains – Land, Fleet, Air and Joint Enablers.
The MSPs will be a key provider of the services / requirements driving the DE&S Materiel Strategy change programme. They will drive a step-change improvement of project delivery across DE&S, be it procuring new military equipment, commodities and services, supporting in-service equipment through-life or managing global logistics operations. The MSPs will design, build, implement, help operate and embed a system of project management techniques and project controls across DE&S that will improve effectiveness and efficiency of its output delivery.

For this requirement project delivery is used to describe the totality of the products and services that DE&S delivers to MOD, be it procuring new military equipment, commodities and services, supporting in-service equipment through-life or managing global logistics operations.
This requirement is part of the DE&S's wider Materiel Strategy change programme. Under the change programme, the DE&S organisation has been established as a Bespoke Central Government Trading Entity within the public sector from 01/04/14, with new management freedoms and controls that are appropriate to its challenges and the specialist nature of its business.

Requirement

The Work Package is split into four contracts covering project delivery of each of the four Domains – Land, Fleet, Air and Joint Enablers.
The MSPs will be a key provider of the services / requirements driving the DE&S Materiel Strategy change programme. They will drive a step-change improvement of project delivery across DE&S, be it procuring new military equipment, commodities and services, supporting in-service equipment through-life or managing global logistics operations. The MSPs will design, build, implement, help operate and embed a system of project management techniques and project controls across DE&S that will improve effectiveness and efficiency of its output delivery.

Title: GB-UK: Enhanced Individual Protective Equipment
Description:
THIS REQUIREMENT HAS BEEN ISSUED AS AN SBRI CHALLENGE AND DETAILS CAN BE VIEWED ON THE INNOVATE UK WEBSITE.THIS MOD DCO NOTICE IS PUBLISHED AS A DUPLICATE TO ENSURE FULL COVERAGE.
Up to £1m is available for Phase1 of this 2 phase competition funded by the Ministry of Defence (MOD).
 
The mission of the MOD's Defence Equipment and Support (DE&S) is "To equip and support our Armed Forces for operations now and in the future." DE&S is responsible for procuring and supporting all the equipment and services for the UK Armed Forces.
 
There is a need to improve the energy consumption of UK MOD military assets through Sustainable Development. This MOD call seeks proposals for novel ideas to reduce the cost of ownership of military assets through innovative approaches to fuel and lubrication use. 
 
The primary goal for this research is to meet reductions in operational energy usage targets. A secondary goal is to improve mechanical operation and maintenance techniques through smarter lubricant and fuel use. 
 
This challenge is broken into two themes:
 
•	Theme 1. Reduce fuel and lubricant consumption. MOD are looking for novel ways to reduce dependency on fuels and lubricants, in a way which reduces asset cost of ownership whilst maintaining or improving capability.
 
Areas of research not limited to: improving efficiency, smart energy management, improving dynamics, novel fuels, reducing lubricant waste, managing the effects of microbiological growth in fuel, waste regeneration and smarter asset employment. 
 
•	Theme 2. Enhanced operation and maintenance. MOD are looking for novel ways to improve mechanical operation and maintenance techniques of platforms through smarter lubricant and fuel use, in a way which reduces asset cost of ownership whilst maintaining or improving capability.  
 
Areas of research not limited to: more effective lubrication, improving contamination detection, reducing contamination, lubricant condition based maintenance, detection and prediction of incipient component failure. 
 
Phase 2 funding to develop working prototypes will be available for those projects that demonstrate the greatest potential at the end of the Phase 1 contract.
 
This competition opens on Monday 8th June and will close at 12 noon on Wednesday, 5th August, 2015.
 
A briefing event will be held in London on Tuesday 14 July 2015. Register for this event here.
 
All proposals must be submitted via the Innovate UK portal. 
 
Application Process 
This competition is run by Innovate UK. 
 
Open Date: 8th June 2015
Registration Closes: 29th July 2015
Close Date:  5th August 2015
Additional Text:
The contracting authority considers that this contract may be suitable for economic operators that are small or medium enterprises (SMEs). However, any selection of tenderers will be based solely on the criteria set out for the procurement, and the contract will be awarded on the basis of the most economically advantageous tender.
Electronic Trading: Potential suppliers must note the mandatory requirement for electronic trading using the Ministry of Defence's standard Purchase to Payment (P2P) system operating under the Defence Electronic Commerce Service, which shall be a special condition for performance of this Contract. You can find details on the P2P system at www.d2btrade.com. The Contractor shall be required to sign DEFFORM 30 (Electronic Transaction Agreements) and unconditionally accept DEFCON 5J (Unique Identifiers) DEFCON 129J (The Use of Electronic Business Delivery Form) and DEFCON 522J (Payment under P2P)

orgName: Ministry of Defence, Air Support, Air Commodities Project Team
Title: United Kingdom-Bristol: Repair, maintenance and associated services related to aircraft and other equipment
Description:
Repair, maintenance and associated services related to aircraft and other equipment. Aircraft-operation services. The Air Commodities Team has a requirement to procure a Support Solution for the provision of engineering support of Aircraft Arrestor Systems in use across the UK and Overseas at military air bases.

The UK MOD currently utilises a fleet of 18 Air Transportable deployable Portable Aircraft Arresting Gear (PAAG) P-IV/BAK-12 and 30 installed Rotary Hydraulic Arrestor Gear (RHAG Mk1) Model 44B-3A Water Twister Energy Absorption systems from Engineered Arresting Systems Corporation (ESCO) as the Original Equipment Manufacture 

These systems fulfil the subject capability for MOD Main Operating Bases (MOB), Permanent Joint Operating Bases (PJOB) and overseas Deployed Operating Bases (DOB) which operate Fixed Wing Training and Fast Jet military aircraft.

A spares inclusive availability based support contract is required for 10 years to provide engineering support including but not limited to;
refurbishment & repair of major assemblies,
Post Design Services,
RHAG & PAAG tapes,

The Authority has split this requirement into lots; 

Lot 1: RHAG / PAAG

This VEAT is only applicable to LOT 1. 

Lot 2: Barrier will continue under the restricted procedure (competition), a Contract Award Notice will be issued in due course.

Title: The Provision of a Verbatim Court Recording Service to the MCS
Description:
TRANSPARENCY NOTICE OF ITN ISSUE; THIS REQUIREMENT WAS ADVERTISED UNDER OJEU Notice:-2015/5132-243539 and closed for EOFI on 7 AUGUST 2015. 
ARMYHQ2/00028-The Provision of a Verbatim Court Recording Service to the Military Court Service 
The requirement is for the provision of a Verbatim Court Recorder’s (VCR) service at all Service Court proceedings in the Court Martial, the Service Civilian Court and the Summary Appeal Court for the Army, Royal Air Force and Royal Navy (including Royal Marines). The service is also required to cover judicial hearings, Army Board Oral Hearings (OH) and Service Inquiries (SI) convened by the Army.  These proceedings, hearings and inquiries are predominantly held at the 5 permanent Military Court Centres (MCCs), four of which are located in the United Kingdom (at  Bulford, Colchester, Catterick and Portsmouth) and the fifth at Sennelager in Germany. The principal requirement is for VCRs in UK and Germany, but there is also potentially a requirement to support Court proceedings, hearings and inquiries on a global basis. For instance, in recent years occasional proceedings have been held in Cyprus, Brunei, Belize, Gilbraltar, Canada, Kosovo, the Falkland Islands and USA.

orgName: Ministry of Defence, ISTAR, Chemical, Biological, Radiological and Nuclear Delivery Team (CBRN DT)
Title: CBRN/00215 APED In-Service Support
Description:
The Chemical, Biological, Radiological and Nuclear Delivery Team (CBRN DT) has a future requirement to sustain Aircrew Protective Equipment for a period of 4-5 years commencing Jan 17.
The equipment is used by aircrew flying battlefield support helicopters, providing each crewman with a bespoke MAHIS (Military Aircrew Helmet Impact Standard) compliant flight helmet integrated to a Faceshield Respirator (FSR) and a Manside System (comprising a CBRN Air Filter, Blower, Battery and Battery Interface assemblies). This equipment provides the equipped aircrew with a CBRN respirator system integrated with, but operating independently of the aircraft’s systems.
The system was introduced into service in 2012 and equips 3 UK military formations, the current build standard was defined and frozen at the completion of the project’s assessment phase (Apr 2015). This contract is designed to maintain the availability of the system at this build standard. The main elements of the contract deliverables are:
a. Maintenance of the System Specification and Final Declaration of Design Performance
b. Management of the DRACAS (Data, Reporting, Analysis and Corrective Action System)
c. Head Scanning – providing a head-scanning service to ensure that all aircrew requiring to be fitted with APED have their heads measured and data recorded to enable:
d. Custom Fit Protective Liner (CFPL) to be produced for each APED equipped aircrew.    
e. Ad hoc Provision of equipment required for Qualification and Flight Testing, Training development and delivery. 
f. SME support to Qualification, Flight testing and technical investigations
g. Provision of Capital and Consumable Spares 
h. Ad hoc support tasks 
To note: the OEM is known to own patent(s) relating to the equipment, particularly with relevance to items c and d.
Additional Text:

http://www.contracts.mod.uk/delta/signup.html?userType=supplier

and search for the notice with reference 'UK-Bristol: Military helmets.'.

Title: SBRI  Challenge - Fuels and Lubricants
Description:
The work is to be undertaken in accordance with the SBRI application 61067-444228 part 8 submitted to and held by Innovate UK for the Fuels and Lubricants programme.
Develop a contact mode instrument to measure critical parameters of surface morphology which determine drag on military aircraft surfaces.
The key deliverables of the project are as follows:
1. Establish representative surfaces to be found on MOD aircraft and establish an experimental optical analysis rig.
2. Explore approaches and algorithms, down select candidates and develop to a stage where a prototype instrument can be specified.
3. Design, manufacture and validate a prototype on laboratory samples representative of military aircraft surfaces.
4. Validate laboratory results by testing on static aircraft.
5. Deliver a final Phase 1 report.

Title: Justification of the decision of the procurer to award the contract without the prior publication of a contract notice:
Description:
The Unmanned Air Systems Team, part of the UK Ministry of Defence (“MoD”), intends to acquire the PROTECTOR Unmanned Aerial System through a Government -Government Foreign Military Sales (FMS) Contract with the US Department of Defence (US DoD). The MoD has conducted a thorough Assessment Phase (AP) which has concluded that the Certifiable Predator B (CPB) is the only system capable of achieving UK Military Type Certification (MTC) and delivering the PROTECTOR requirement within the required timescales.  The only means of acquiring the CPB is through a contract with the US DoD.  
The Defence and Security Public Contract Regulations 2011 do not apply to the proposed contract with the US DoD by virtue of Regulation 7(1)(h)(i).

Title: Future Operational Ration Packs
Description:
Team Leidos, under the scope of the Logistics Commodities Support (Transformation) - LCS(T) contract, has a requirement for the supply of a range of Operational Ration Packs (ORP) to support expeditionary military operations and exercises undertaken by the UK Armed Forces. 
A flexible range of rations are required to meet the cognitive, nutritional and energy needs of the servicemen and women in the field. Due to the transient nature of military operations, routinely taking place all over the world, the ORP components will need to withstand a variety of climates and have an extended shelf life on delivery into the designated storage facility, which is currently planned to be the Defence Fulfilment Centre in Donnington, Shropshire. 
The ORP requirement has been split over four individual lots as follows: Lot 1 - Supply of Food Components and Sundry Items; Lot 2 - Supply of Packaging Materials; Lot 3 - Packing of ORP, and; Lot 4 - Supply of Survival Rations. 
The main ORP is the 24-Hr ORP, which typically consists of wet or freeze-dried main meal pouches (breakfast, lunch and dinner), snacks (chocolate bars, fruit/cereal bars, sweets and nuts, etc), fruit purees and powdered drinks, chewing gum, tea/coffee, whiteners, sugar, water sterilisation tablets, flameless ration heaters or windproof/waterproof matches, wet wipes, tissues and eating utensils.
Leidos is seeking to order food components, sundry items and packaging materials from suppliers (Lots 1 and 2) for delivery into a packing supplier for consolidation and onward delivery to the designated storage facility (Lot 3). The food components and sundry items have the requirement of a shelf life of not less than 24 months on delivery into the designated storage facility.
Survival Rations (Lot 4) are to be treated separately to this and will be procured as complete ration packs, delivered directly from the supplier to the designated storage facility. The survival rations have the additional requirement of a shelf life of not less than 48 months on delivery into the designated storage facility.
Leidos intends to award Lot 1 on an individual line item basis and Lots 2, 3 and 4 on a total Lot basis.
The anticipated contract award date is April 2017 for a service commencement date of 4th October 2017.  The contract duration is 2 years with an additional two 1 year option periods.
Additional Text: Interested parties should register at the Leidos Supplier Portal to access our online tendering system, see link above. Further details can be found in the OJEU advert that has now been published (ref: 2016/S 215-392158).

orgName: Ministry of Defence, DIO, Defence Infrastructure Organisation (DIO)
Title: A Better Defence Estate
Description: The better defence estate strategy aims to support military capability by providing a smaller but better estate for the armed forces & their families out to 2040 and beyond. A detailed, long term plan to reduce the defence built estate by 30% & provides a framework for the geographical lay down of our forces in the UK for at least a generation. Developed in partnership with military leaders it sets out where investment will be concentrated & sites that will be sold. DIO is currently developing its strategy to meet the overall aims, through developing a supplier engagement framework and an appropriate engagement route to keep communication channels open and engaging to the widest network, ranging from major Public Limited Companies (PLCs) to Medium and Small to Medium Enterprise (SME) Suppliers.

Title: DFID 7670 Hostile Environment Training
Description: The Stabilisation Unit (SU) is the Government's centre of expertise and best practice in stabilisation. Set up to respond to the complex challenges of fragile and conflict afflicted states, it is a uniquely integrated civil-military operational unit, designed to be agile and responsive and well-equipped to operate in high threat environments. It combines in-house staff expertise with the ability to draw on a larger pool of civilian expertise for specialised, longer term or larger scale takings to work with countries on conflict, stabilisation and security issues. The Unit reports to the National Security Council and has a core staff from twelve government departments, police and three military services, many of whom join the unit on secondment on a two to three year basis. As part of the SU's unique role to deploy to FCAS states, the SU requires all personnel selected for deployment on behalf of Her Majesty's Government (HMG) to undertake specific pre-deployment training, currently for over 350 personnel a year. The appropriate selection, training and accreditation of suitable personnel is integral to the SU's ability to mitigate the foreseeable risks that its deployees may face in fragile and conflict affected environments around the world. A major piece of the SU's remit is its ability to deploy personnel both bilaterally to HMG platforms and to multilateral platforms with the EU, UN, and NATO in an agile and flexible manner. The UK's Stabilisation Unit (SU) is seeking partners to develop and manage a new training programme for deployees travelling and working in FCAS.
Additional Text:
All relevant information relating to this Contract Notice can be found on the DFID Supplier Portal where suppliers can register their interest directly.

If you are not already registered as a supplier on the DFID Supplier Portal please follow the guidance which can be found on the top left of the home page: https://supplierportal.dfid.gov.uk/selfservice/

Title: BFG FUNERAL SERVICES
Description: Funeral Services - the recovery and transfer of the deceased from locations within or outside the borders of Germany to the British Forces Germany (BFG) Designated Mortuary, located with Stadt Klinikum Gutersloh and other locations as defined by the Authority.  It is essential that the Royal Military Police (RMP) have the means to request fast and immediate recovered of the deceased, especially when death occurs outside hospitals, in order to ensure security and integrity of potential investigative evidence for pathology purposes.  The preparation of the deceased, this includes (once permission to do so has been given by the RMP) the fitting and/or removal of clothing prior to viewing by the next of kin; provision for, on request from G1 Cas Comp, funeral services for local burials (in British Military Cemeteries or local cemeteries) including the provision of suitable coffins (as detailed in the Statement of Requirement (SOR); arrangment of documentation and liaison with local crematoriums as necessary.

Title: Programme CORTISONE - (for transparency purposes only)
Description:
THE ITT HAS ALREADY BEEN SENT OUT THIS NOTICE IS FOR TRANSPARENCY PURPOSES ONLY - Provision of Integrated Medical Information Services - Programme CORTISONE 

Lot 1:
This Lot Solution will provide the foundation to enable the required business outcome of an integrated Electronic Health Record. An iEHR is an organised collection of patient healthcare data stored in a digital format.

This Lot Solution will deliver the underpinning Med IS architecture for CORTISONE that will allow clinicians/users to view, create, exchange and share health and healthcare information, across Defence (all DMS environments, fixed and deployed) and through a variety of secure interfaces, with various non-DMS healthcare providers (eg NHS (UK ('four nation' health services)), NATO and other allies).  

Lot 2:
This lot will enable the business outcome of an ability to exploit all the healthcare data in records by transforming it into useful information.

The Lot Solution will enable data from anywhere in the medical information services architecture to be used to produce reports at any level of abstraction. This will include simple reports for a single clinician about a single patient, aggregated statistics for military formation HQs and data analytics across the entire medical data set. 

Lot 3:
This is the core general practice (GP) service. This Lot Solution will enable the DMS user to access and record all the information required to safely, efficiently and effectively deliver primary healthcare. The primary healthcare user shall be able to record all details of a patient's contact with any health professional or healthcare administrator in all DMS environments (fixed and deployed). This service will cover areas such as consultations, protocols, summaries, document management, practice management, medicines management, referrals management, appointment management, telemedicine and clinical decision support tools.

Lot 4:
This Lot Solution will deliver services to enable the user to be able to manage all data relating to dental healthcare delivery activities, including those that are military specific, in all DMS environments (fixed and deployed). This includes the management of consultations, referrals, diagnostic tests, decision support tools, dental charts, dental treatment plans, periodontal charts, NATO dental fitness categories, laboratory work e.g. dentures/ crowns, dental specialties e.g. orthodontics, periodontology, oral surgery, forensics and digital dental radiography (intraoral) and telemedicine. 

Lot 7:
This Lot Solution will deliver services to enable the user to be able to access an Electronic Radiology Management System (ERMS). This will enable the prescribing, capture, reporting and archiving of all medical images such as radiographs, ultrasound scans, MRI scans, including dental.
Additional Text:
Please note that this is a lot-based tender and that the estimated contract values above relate to the highest value and lowest value lots. Estimated contract value per lot is as follows:

Lot 1 - £8.86M
Lot 2 - £5M
Lot 3 - £5.6M
Lot 4 - £1.4M
Lot 7 - £1.2M
