Title: GB-Huntingdon: ED76 Assessment of No 1 AIDU Production Process
Description:
NOTE: This notice was updated on 11 July 2017 for the following reason: Section 12 of the original notice states that the deadline for submitting your response(s) is 28/07/2018 17:00.  As detailed elsewhere in the notice, the deadline is 09/08/2017 10:00.No 1 Aeronautical Information Document Unit (No 1 AIDU) at RAF Northolt is responsible to the MoD for the publication & distribution of all permanent unclassified information concerning any aeronautical facility, service, procedure or hazard required by UK Military personnel directly concerned with the operation & safety of aircraft. To support the on-going provision of Aeronautical Information suitable for new Area Navigation applications an independent assessment of No 1 AIDU compliance with ED-76A/RTCA DO200B is required.
      As a military establishment No 1 AIDU is unable to gain approval from Civil ATM organisations & regulators such as EASA or EUROCONTROL SRC. All organisations claiming compliance with the standards of ED-76A must demonstrate such compliance, normally by audit. As such, No 1 AIDU is looking for an independent company with relevant Aeronautical Information experience to audit No 1 AIDU for compliance with the requirements of ED-76A.
      Potential Providers must be BSI EN ISO 9001: 2008 or 2015 accredited & must have previously successfully undertaken an ED-76 or ED-76A audit.
      The Unit currently holds a Certificate of ED-76A Compliance which was obtained in November 2015, & the successful Provider will be required to review the current documentation & processes, prepare an Audit plan prior to conducting a formal Audit, & provide a full Audit report.
      
      Please see 'Other Information' below for important details for those wishing to submit documentation in support of this procurement.

Title: Real Life Support Provision for Watchkeeper Operational Field Trials
Description:
Background.  Watchkeeper (WK), the Army's Tactical Unmanned Air System, will undertake Operational Field Trials (OFT) from 18 Sep - 5 Nov 17.  A Military Permit for Trials Flying (MPTF) has been issued for these trials, which will run under the Accountable Manager (Military Flying) for the Thales Flight Operations Organisation (FOO).  The Thales FOO operate from West Wales Airport, in Aberporth, using the adjacent range danger areas in Cardigan Bay for all WK trials activity.  The MPTF ties Thales FOO to West Wales Airport for the OFT. 
      
      Army support is required to both facilitate and add realism to the OFT.  A full WK sub-unit will deploy to West Wales Airport over the 7 week trial period.  A tented camp will be built to  accommodate the 80-120 personnel participating in the trial; this camp must be properly established with cooking facilities ablutions and enabling utilities and facilities (water, power, infrastructure).

orgName: N E L Commissioning Support Unit
Title: Veterans Mental Health Intensive Services - NHS England
Description:
The NHS Commissioning Board, known as NHS England, the Contracting Authority, (hereafter referred to as "The Authority") invites completed Invitation to Tender (ITT) submissions from all suitable providers to provide the Veterans' Mental Health - Intensive Service in one or more of these following opportunities; North, Midlands & East, London & South East and South West & South Central.


In 2017 NHS England commissioned the veterans' mental health Transition Intervention and Liaison service (TIL) following publication of the engagement work in relation to veterans mental health services.  TIL services provide across England increased access and treatment for armed forces personnel approaching discharge and veterans with mental health difficulties. 


Building on the VMH - TIL service the VMH Intensive Service (VMH - IS) will provide an enhanced service for veterans with complex mental health problems that are attributable to military service, which have not been resolved earlier in the care / support pathway and require an intensive and assertive multi-disciplinary package of clinical and social interventions where a military culturally sensitive approach would assist the rapport and therapeutic outcomes for the patient. The service will focus on those veterans who have complex mental health problems including PTSD.


The aim of the Procurement is to: have a consistent service model and patient offer across England; support more veterans than are currently able to access the Intensive Treatment Programme; ensure care is provided closer to home; have common performance metrics across the services.


Contracts will be awarded for an initial period of two (2) years, with optional extension for a further two (2) years. i.e. Maximum total duration for each contract is four (4) years in total.


The Procurement process will be facilitated entirely online via The Authority's e-procurement portal (ProContract). Interested Applicants wishing to participate in the procurement must register and complete the online questionnaires hosted on the portal prior to the deadline for submission. All clarification requests and correspondence pertaining to this ITT opportunity must be directed through the portal. 


A timetable for the procurement, guidance regarding the process, and supplementary information relating to each contract opportunity is also available from the Portal. 


Bidders are also to note that information relating to this procurement is provided in good faith, and may be subject to 
amendment by The Authority.
Region: North East,North West,Yorkshire and The Humber,East Midlands,West Midlands,East of England,London,South East,South West
Additional Text: This Tender process is being managed by NEL Commissioning Support Unit (NEL CSU) on behalf of The Authority in connection with a competitive procurement exercise that is being conducted in accordance with a process based on the Open Procedure under the Public Contract Regulations 2015 ("the Regulations" (as amended)). The services to which this Procurement relates fall within the "Light Touch Regime" (LTR) governing procurement of Health, Social, Education and Other service contracts. Neither the reference to "Open Procedure", "ITT", "SQ", the use of the term "Tender process", nor any other indication shall be taken to mean that the Contracting Authority intends to hold itself bound to any of the Regulations, save those applicable to LTR provisions.

Title: GB-Salisbury: DATA ACQUISITION SYSTEMS (DAS) FOR VIBRATION AND NOISE
Description:
Dstl requires five portable DAS for measurement and recording of whole-body vibration, hand-arm vibration and airborne noise in a wide range of military land platforms for the purpose of evaluation and assessment the effects on comfort and health as per current British and International Standards and UK Legislation CVAWR2005 and CNAWR2005. The systems will enable capture of continuous time-history measurements of vibration acceleration and interior sound pressure level at various crew positions within military land vehicles simultaneously with video and GPS data. One 'Full Setup' system and four (or minimum of three) 'Light Setup' systems are needed. The systems will be used in extremely harsh motion environments and must be robust and highly ruggedized to prevent damage
      
      Characteristics of the measuring systems, including accelerometers, mounting system, data acquisition, recording system, signal conditioning and calibrator, shall conform to ISO8041(2005), BSEN61672-1:2013 and BSEN61010-1:2010 or equivalent. The equipment set-up to comply with ISO2631-1(1997), ISO5349-1(2001) and BSEN61672-1:2013. The instrumentation and associated signal conditions shall give vibration and sound pressure level measurement errors no greater than ±5% of the measured value.
      CCTV video of the interior of the vehicle and forward visual scene shall be able to record at a rate no less than 25 frames per second. The video recordings shall be acquired at a resolution no less than 640 by 480 pixels. 
      Each system shall allow all required vibration data to be collected simultaneously into the same acquisition system. The inter-channel characteristics (i.e. phase delay between channels) shall be specified. 
      Each system shall allow vehicle speed to be recorded with an accuracy of at least ±1 mph and vehicle position to be recorded with an error no greater than 5 m. It should be possible to relate the GPS and video recordings to the measured accelerations to an accuracy of at least 0.5 seconds.
      Each system will provide vibration, sound pressure level, GSP and video recordings in a suitable specified format for use by others and for archival storage. 
      Each system will be provided with data acquisition and post-processing software for measurement, evaluation and assessment of human exposures to vibration and noise in accord with current British and International Standards and UK Legislation, including ISO2631-1:1997,  ISO5349-1:2001, ISO8041:2005, BSEN 61672-1:2013, CVAWR2005, CNAWR2005 and DEFSTAN00-27.
      Commissioning, testing and half-day training (up to five persons at Authority's premises) at the time of delivery is required. Two-year support contract for  software (e.g. helpline, upgrade) is required and a minimum one-year warranty for Data Loggers.
      
      Detailed Statement of Requirement of both systems and Invitation to Tender documentation are available from Mike Young (myoung1@dstl.gov.uk). All tenders must be returned by 1300 on 15 September 2017.
Additional Text:

Title: GB-Birmingham: JFC6C/00029 for the Provision of Physical Development Facilities for Royal Centre for Defence Medicine Personnel
Description:
NOTE: This notice was updated on 19 October 2017 for the following reason: The Tender Submission Deadline has been extended to 1200hrs on Thursday 26 October 2017.The Authority has a requirement for the provision of Physical Training Facility access for Royal Centre for Defence Medicine (RCDM) Personnel at Queen Elizabeth Hospital (QEH) in Birmingham. The proposed Contract shall be for a period of 3 years with the option to extend for a further year with an anticipated Contract Commencement date of 1 January 2018.  
      
      The successful Bidder shall be situated within close proximity to the Queen Elizabeth Hospital, with no longer than 30 minutes travel time from door to door on foot.  The facility shall enable delivery of military instructor-led training sessions to maintain, and improve, the physical fitness of military personnel to enable effective deployment on worldwide operations.
      
      The main requirement is for access to a Sports Hall that can accommodate training sessions for up to 60 personnel with the associated access to changing facilities and physical training equipment.  The sessions are to number 15 per week (Mon-Fri) and have a regular agreed timetable within the overall Gym programme.  
      
      The successful Service Provider shall demonstrate that they can provide the required access to facilities as per the Statement of Requirement.  
      
      The Service Provider shall provide 9 core sessions at stipulated timings (Mon-Fri) with 6 additional sessions to be agreed after contract award with the end user (Mon-Fri) within 0800-2000hrs time window.   
      
      Within a 12 month period it is estimated that a total of 750 sessions shall be required, although these figures may fluctuate in accordance with demand.
      
      The evaluation criterion for this requirement is Most Economically Advantageous to Tender (MEAT) with an agreed scoring weighting of 60 Technical and 40 Price. 
      
      Should you have any questions please contact Lisa Buckley, Commercial Manager on DEFComrclCC-JFC7b@mod.uk.

Title: Veterans' Mental Health Complex Treatment Service
Description:
The NHS Commissioning Board, known as NHS England, the Contracting Authority, (hereafter referred to as "The Authority") invites completed Invitation to Tender (ITT) submissions from all suitable providers to provide the Veterans' Mental Health - Complex Treatment Service in one or more of these following opportunities; East Midlands, West Midlands and East of England. 
In 2017 NHS England commissioned the Veterans' Mental Health Transition Intervention and Liaison (TIL) service following publication of the engagement work in relation to veterans' mental health services.  TIL services provide, across England, increased access and treatment for armed forces personnel approaching discharge and veterans with mental health difficulties. 
Building on the VMH - TIL service the VMH Complex Treatment Service (VMH - CTS) will provide an enhanced service for veterans with complex mental health problems that are attributable to military service, which have not been resolved earlier in the care / support pathway and require an intensive and assertive multi-disciplinary package of clinical and social interventions where a military culturally sensitive approach would assist the rapport and therapeutic outcomes for the patient. The service will focus on those veterans who have complex mental health problems including PTSD.
The Procurement process will be facilitated entirely online via The Authority's e-procurement portal (ProContract). This opportunity was previously advertised as part of the Veterans Mental Health - Intensive Service as Lot 2 - Midlands & East (PRJ437) which failed to attract any bids in this configuration. orgName: N E L Commissioning Support Unit
Title: NHS England Veterans Mental Health Intensive Service - Market Engagement Event
Description:
NHS England would like to invite providers to attend a Market Engagement Event which will inform the market of the intentions to procure Veterans Mental Health Intensive Service Nationally.

In 2017 NHS England Commissioned the veterans' mental health Transition Intervention and Liaison service (TIL) following publication of the engagement work in relation to veterans mental health services. 
TIL services provide across England increased access and treatment for armed forces personnel approaching discharge and veterans with mental health difficulties. 
There are three elements to TILs - a transition service for those leaving the armed forces, an intervention service for veterans who have more complex presentations and would benefit from being seen by a clinician with expert understanding of armed forces life and culture; and a liaison service for those who do not have complex presentations but would benefit from treatment and support.

Building on the VMH - TIL service the VMH Intensive Service (VMH - IS) will provide an enhanced service for veterans with complex mental health problems that are attributable to military service, which have not been resolved earlier in the care / support pathway and require an intensive and assertive multi-disciplinary package of clinical and social interventions where a military culturally sensitive approach would assist the rapport and therapeutic outcomes for the patient. The service will focus on those veterans who have complex mental health problems including PTSD.
The opportunity will be open to the entire market. 

It is intended that a procurement process will commence in August with a view for the services to commence on the 1st April 2018. 

 The Market Engagement stage will be conducted in two phases and we have supplied the draft specification along with this advert for early access:

Phase 1 - Market Survey 
(Closing date for this survey is 23.45 hrs 17/07/17)
This is a survey that we are inviting you to complete by following the link below, the survey is designed to elicit constructive, helpful feedback that can be considered by the Commissioner for inclusion, where possible in the process.

Phase 2 - Market Engagement Event 
The Market Engagement Event will take place on the 31st July 2017 from 10:30 - 12:00 at:
Holiday Inn London - Regent's Park 
Carburton Street, 
London, 
W1W 5EE
Market Engagement Event will provide: 
•	an overview of the services to be provided
•	details of the anticipated contract type, length and particular conditions
•	an overview of the procurement process and the anticipated timeline 

Places are limited therefore reservations are limited to no more than 2 persons per organisation. 

To reserve your place please complete the registration form and email the completed form to david.singleton2@nhs.net before 24th July 2017, please ensure the following is completed:

•	Name of delegate
•	Job title of delegate
•	Organisation details, including address
•	Delegate email addresses
Region: North East,North West,Yorkshire and The Humber,East Midlands,West Midlands,East of England,London,South East,South West
Attachments: VMHI Service Service Specification FINAL DRAFT 210617.pdf VMHI Lot Geography.pdf Market Engagement Event_Attendee Registration Form.xlsx
Additional Text:
Please note this is purely a market assessment exercise to gather facts and generate interest. The subsequent procurement will be advertised separately and all organisations wanting to participate will need to respond to the procurement advertisement as and when published.
Following the event, the Authority will share the presentation and any appropriate feedback with those that have registered for the event. Please ensure that you indicate on your registration form if you wish for your details to be shared or not. When responding via email to register for this event please use the following in the subject field of your email : "VMHI Registration Form for Market Engagement Event".

The ITT, when published, will be advertised on the Contracts Finder website (https://www.contractsfinder.service.gov.uk/Search) and will be run through the https://procontract.due-north.com/register procurement portal 
We recommend that you register with both of these websites in the meantime to save you time later in the process.

Please ensure that you arrive at the phase 2, Market Engagement Event venue 15 minutes before the scheduled start time to allow for security and registration

Please find attached the lot geography proposed that splits the national geography into four lots, this proposal may be subject to organisational change.

Title: GB-Glasgow: Provision of Critical Care Placements for the Physiotherapy Deployed Hospital Care Course (PDHCC)
Description:
The Authority has a requirement for the provision of military physiotherapy critical care placements.  The proposed framework agreement shall be for a period of 3 years commencing 1 Apr 2018 and ending 31 Mar 2021 with an option to extend for a further 2 years.
      
      The successful Service Provider shall provide clinical placements for qualified military physiotherapists in order to refresh Band 5 level competency and skills in trauma/critical care prior to operational deployment. 
      
      The Service Provider shall provide clinical placements for up to 10 post-registration physiotherapists per annum. Each placement will consist of a 2 week clinical practice under the supervision of a Band 7 (minimum) physiotherapist. It is envisaged that the requirement will be split over a number of individual contracts per organisation. 
      
      Within a 12 month period it is estimated that a maximum total of 5 shall be required, although these figures may fluctuate in accordance with demand.
      
      The evaluation criterion for this requirement is detailed below: 
      
      This Tender will be evaluated using MEAT the Most Economically Advantageous Tender method. Your Tender must meet the minimum technical standard, as stated in the Tender documentation, to be deemed technically compliant. 
      
      Should you have any questions please contact Aileen McLynn, Commercial Manager on DefComrclCC-JFC6a@mod.uk.

Title: COEFOR Support (Project Thespis)
Description:
Project Thespis will deliver the future Contemporary Operating Environment Force (COEFOR) capability to Support individual and collective Training. The capability shall provide training support services that are agile, responsive and capable of representing uniformed forces, governmental departments, NGOs, Demonstration Forces (DEMFOR), Opposing Forces (OPFOR), Subject Matter Experts (SME), private contracted forces, casualties including the breadth and depth of civilian population and institutions that will be consistent with the Conceptual Operating Environment SCENario (COESCEN) and Decisive Action Training Environment (DATE), augmented with conceptual language and cultural training to create realistic environments representing current and emerging threats.
      
      COEFOR Support to training includes, but is not limited to:
      
      •	The physical manifestation of an operating environment to match the given scenario for the specified training establishment/training event.
      
      •	Representative uniformed forces ranging from allied through neutral and indigenous to opposing, such as military, paramilitary, police, OPFOR and DEMFOR and represent bodies across the full spectrum of the given scenario nationalities/geographical environment (government officials, military, civilians etc).
      
      •	Representation of the breadth and depth of a civilian population, including its customs, dress and tribal dynamics that will effectively represent the true complexities of communities, religions, tribes and the key personalities of the scenario. 
      
      •	Provision of Casualty Simulation (CASSIM) to specific training scenarios that depict realistic clinical events. These clinical events will include all battle, disease and non-battle injuries present in contemporary operations, including, but not limited to, amputation simulation appropriate to ballistic/blast injury, gunshot wound injury, burn injuries, open fracture simulation and casualty make up depicting minor wounds. 
      
      •	A wide range of role players in a dynamic, intelligent and flexible manner. 
      
      •	Support to conceptual activity through interpreters (role play and real time), language and cultural training.
      
      •	Scenario Writers and pyrotechnic effects simulation.
      
      •	Provision of the logistics required to deliver training support to small, medium and large scale events, including, but not limited to, provision and management of feeding, transport to and from events, accommodation, clothing, props and equipment.

The systems will be used in extremely harsh motion environments and must be robust and highly ruggedized to prevent damage
      
      Characteristics of the measuring systems, including accelerometers, mounting system, data acquisition, recording system, signal conditioning and calibrator, shall conform to ISO8041(2005), BSEN61672-1:2013 and BSEN61010-1:2010 or equivalent. The equipment set-up to comply with ISO2631-1(1997), ISO5349-1(2001) and BSEN61672-1:2013. The instrumentation and associated signal conditions shall give vibration and sound pressure level measurement errors no greater than ±5% of the measured value.
      CCTV video of the interior of the vehicle and forward visual scene shall be able to record at a rate no less than 25 frames per second. The video recordings shall be acquired at a resolution no less than 640 by 480 pixels. 
      Each system shall allow all required vibration data to be collected simultaneously into the same acquisition system. The inter-channel characteristics (i.e. phase delay between channels) shall be specified. 
      Each system shall allow vehicle speed to be recorded with an accuracy of at least ±1 mph and vehicle position to be recorded with an error no greater than 5 m. It should be possible to relate the GPS and video recordings to the measured accelerations to an accuracy of at least 0.5 seconds.
      Each system will provide vibration, sound pressure level, GSP and video recordings in a suitable specified format for use by others and for archival storage. 
      Each system will be provided with data acquisition and post-processing software for measurement, evaluation and assessment of human exposures to vibration and noise in accord with current British and International Standards and UK Legislation, including ISO2631-1:1997,  ISO5349-1:2001, ISO8041:2005, BSEN 61672-1:2013, CVAWR2005, CNAWR2005 and DEFSTAN00-27.
      Commissioning, testing and half-day training (up to five persons at Authority's premises) at the time of delivery is required. Two-year support contract for  software (e.g. helpline, upgrade) is required and a minimum one-year warranty for Data Loggers.
      
      Detailed Statement of Requirement of both systems and Invitation to Tender documentation are available from Mike Young (myoung1@dstl.gov.uk). All tenders must be returned by 1300 on 15 September 2017.

Title: Aerial Surveillance Contract
Description: As an Executive Agency of the Department for Transport (DfT), the Authority develops and implements the Government's maritime safety and environmental protection strategy by, amongst other roles, monitoring the coasts and seas and responding to emergencies. The Authority has two broad objectives: firstly to ensure safety through accident prevention and effective search and rescue coordination and response, improve the safety of ships and people at sea and at the coast; and secondly to protect the environment through monitoring of ships and response to pollution incidents protect the marine environment. The Authority's vision is to be a world-class organisation that is committed to preventing loss of life, continuously improving maritime safety and protecting the coastal environment. In order to achieve its vision the Authority requires the successful supplier to provide a non-military aerial surveillance service to assist with to Search and Rescue and counter pollution operations. The Authority requires the successful supplier (the "Supplier") to provide, following an initial mobilisation and acceptance period potentially of six to eighteen months, a non-military aerial surveillance service for a period of five years plus potential extension periods of up to two years. The Authority requires an all-weather 24/7 capability to provide aerial surveillance, tracking, detection, observation, transmission of data and support to Search and Rescue (SAR) and counter pollution operations within the UK Exclusive Economic Zone ("UKEZZ") and UK Search and Rescue Region ("UKSRR"). This service shall be interoperable with other Government departments and agencies and neighbouring nations. The Authority, through the Aeronautical Rescue Coordination Centre ("ARCC"), will act as the sole tasking authority. In contracting with the Supplier the Authority will be acting on behalf of the Secretary of State for Transport.

Title: Pilot Instrument Rating (NPAS)
Description:
Following a commitment to the UK Civil Aviation Authority, there is a requirement to train up to 40 pilots over the next 5-year period. It is anticipated that 6 to 8 pilots per year will undertake this course from April 2019 and to be completed by 31st December 2022.

The training course will be split into two elements, consisting of the following:

     LOT 1	
A full IR course (50hours) - maximum of 3 courses
Qualified Military Pilot, Procedural IR holders course requiring training "training as required" - max 3 courses
Qualified Military Pilot Non Procedural IR holders requiring a 15 hour course - maximum of 36 courses.

Each course should use the 135 helicopter (provided by the course supplier) with unlimited simulator time, ground school as required and IR skill test. All course material both electronic, paper and up to date maps/ Instrument plates to be supplied.

     LOT 2	
There is also a requirement for a supplier to provide a training package (combination of distance learning and classroom) for a "non-approved" IR ground exam course, for up to 40 pilots.

Title: Spectradynamics Cold Rubidium Clock
Description: DSTL, part of the UK Ministry of Defence, intends to place a contract with SpectraDynamics Inc for the supply of a cold rubidium atomic clock for use in testing the performance of clocks to be used in military environments. It is considered that this contract can be placed using the Negotiated Procedure without Prior Publication of a Contract Notice pursuant to Article 32(2)(b)(ii) of Directive 2014/24/EU (Regulation 32(2)(b)(ii) of the UK Public Contracts Regulations 2015) because competition is absent for technical reasons.  This is because only SpectraDynamics Inc produces an atomic clock having the necessary technical characteristics to meet all DSTL's technical requirements for testing the performance of clocks to be used in military environments.

Title: Provision of Continuous Attitude Surveys to Defence Medical Services
Description:
The Headquarters Surgeon General  is responsible for conducting the Defence Medical Services (DMS) Continuous Attitude Surveys (CAS).  Surveys are conducted for serving military DMS personnel (both regular and reserve) employed within the MOD.  They are used to provide management information to the Defence Medical Services Board and the Personnel Policy Working Group.

As part of various initiatives within the DMS, the key research objective is to identify areas for development that can help inform future HR strategic policy decisions across DMS, including the single Services Medical; Branches.

The Supplier is required to:
1. Produce and deliver, using the most appropriate means, a self-completion questionnaire for on average approximately 10,000 military medical personnel to complete with a method of return to the Contractor within an agreed timeline.  The questionnaire should contain no more than 100 attitudinal questions, 5 non-standard questions, 12 demographic questions and up to four opportunities for open comments.  The sample strategy will be directed by the Designated Officer (DO).

2. Conduct statistical and trend analysis from results over a 3-year period (2016 - 2018).

3.  Provide final reports in hard copy format (2 copies) and soft copy format (1 copy) and data analysis comparator tool in electronic format (licences for 3 people to access the tool) to the DO, 3 weeks prior to the results presentation. 

4. Produce PowerPoint presentations of headline results in a house style agreed between the Contractor and the DO for up to four presentations.  These presentations will then form the verbal feedback from the Contractor to the Authority. 

5. Provide up to 6 days on-site support to the Authority during the survey period to assist with the administration of the survey.

Title: Hazardous Environmental Search Equipment (HESE) in Service Support Contract
Description:
The purpose of this Prior Information Notice (PIN) is to inform potential suppliers that the Authority is holding an early stage Industry day in respect of the future requirement to secure a 3 year support solution for the In-service Hazardous Environment Search Equipment (HESE) suite consisting of circa 25 separate items of equipment, all of which will be based across the UK and Northern Ireland.  
      
      The current In-Service HESE capability provides the equipment necessary for safe access to hazardous working environments, including confined spaces and in spaces where the supply of breathable air cannot be guaranteed.  It is provided through numerous safety equipment that make up the HESE capability, which is required in support of both Military operations and Military Aid to the Civilian Powers (MACP).

Title: Specialist Support for Joint Helicopter Command (JHC) Continuing Airworthiness Management Organisations (CAMOs)
Description:
Joint Helicopter Command has a requirement for Specialist Support Services for multiple Military Continuing Airworthiness Management Organisations (Mil CAMOs), to remain compliant with the Military Aviation Authority (MAA) regulations.There are six Mil CAMOs to be maintained in accordance with the Regulatory Article (RA) 4900 Series, by Suitably Qualified and Experienced Personnel (SQEP).The CAMOs are based at multiple locations nationally and internationally and have some platform specific tasks. 
      One CAMO requires Deputy Continuing Airworthiness Manager (DCAM) support with the others requiring Quality Manager (QM) support. 
      Contractors for DCAM support should understand the requirements outlined in RA 4945(1) 'Personnel Requirements - MRP Part M Sub Part G', noting the Acceptable Means of Compliance listed at Para 1. They should also hold at least, or equivalent: 
            a.	EC(UK) Professional Registration - CEng.
            b. 	Chartered Quality Practitioner (CQP MCQI).
            c. 	Ability to comply with a Competency Framework of a platform specific Continuing Airworthiness Management Exposition (CAME).
      Contractors for QM support should understand the requirements outlined in RA 4951 'Quality System - MRP Part M Sub part G' and should hold at least, or equivalent: 
      a.	Chartered Quality Practitioner (CQP MCQI).
      b.	Quality Assurance Lead Auditor to a recognised standard (ISO 9001:2015 or AS9100).
      It is anticipated that the contract will be in place with effect 29 September 2019 for a 3-year period plus an option for a further one plus one year.
      A Cyber Risk Assessment has been carried out for this requirement. The risk has been assessed as LOW, Reference No: RAR-4M8ZQ6NX. Please respond to the Risk Assessment and demonstrate compliance and include within your tender, further information can be located here - https://www.gov.uk/guidance/supplier-cyber-protection-service.
      Potential Service Providers must read through this set of instructions and follow the process to respond to this opportunity using the access code F84NR6Z88J.
      
      The information and/or documents for this opportunity are available on http://www.contracts.mod.uk/delta. You must register on this site to respond, if you are already registered you will not need to register again, simply use your existing user name and password.Please note there is a password reminder link on the homepage.
      The deadline for submitting your response is 03/06/2019 10:00. Please refer to the FAQs if you have any difficulties.
Contact Address 2: Army Commercial,  IDL437 Zone 8 Floor 2,  Ramillies Building

Title: Operational Ration Packs 2019
Description:
Team Leidos, under the scope of the Logistics Commodities Support (Transformation) - LCS(T) contract, has a requirement for the supply of a range of Operational Ration Packs (ORP) to support expeditionary military operations and exercises undertaken by the UK Armed Forces.

A flexible range of rations are required to meet the cognitive, nutritional and energy needs of the service personnel in the field. Due to the transient nature of military operations, routinely taking place all over the world, the ORP will need to withstand a variety of climates and have an extended shelf life on delivery into the designated storage facility, the Defence Fulfilment Centre in Donnington, Shropshire.

The agreement shall be divided into 4 lots by ration type. The agreement shall be awarded for an initial period of 2 years 10 months from June 2019, with the option of a further 1 year thereafter. The volumes and values provided are for guidance only and are not a guarantee of business.
Additional Text:
The main ORP is the 24-hour GP ration, which currently consists of meal retort pouches (breakfast, lunch and dinner), pudding retort pouches, powdered drinks, sweets, chocolate bars, fruit/cereal bars, nuts, chewing gum, teabags, coffee sachets, whitener sachets, sugar sachets, water sterilisation tablets, wet wipes, a pack of tissues, windproof/waterproof matches and a combined spoon/fork (spork). The current annual consumption volume of the 24-hour GP ration is circa 1.5M rations.

The 24-hour Cultural and Ethnic rations (eg: Halal, Kosher etc) are a variant of the 24-hour GP ration. The current annual consumption volume of all the 24-hour Cultural and Ethnic rations is circa 100K rations. The 24-hour Enhanced and 8-hour Single Meal Rations (SMR) are also a variant of the 24-hour GP ration and additionally include a Flameless Ration Heater. The current annual consumption volume of all the 24-hour Enhanced and 8-hour SMR rations is circa 15K and 80K rations respectively.

All outer cartons shall meet minimum performance criteria, including minimum compression and burst strength and minimum water resistance requirements. All ration cartons are packed on NATO Standard Four-Way Pallets to specified menu stacking requirements and maximum weight and dimensional (including height) requirements. All 24-hour and 8-hour ration packs must have a minimum remaining product shelf life of 24 months (2 years) from the date of delivery into the Defence Fulfilment Centre (DFC).

All rations must meet the specified component requirements and complete ration pack calorific and nutritional values and shall be compliant with Food Safety, Legality and Quality in accordance with EU/UK legislation. The supplier holds responsibility for producing the ORP to meet the specified requirements and to deliver complete rations.

orgName: Ministry of Defence, ISTAR, Chemical, Biological, Radiological and Nuclear Delivery Team (CBRN DT)
Title: The Supply and In-Service Support for Reconnaissance and Exploitation Team (RET)
Description:
The Chemical, Biological, Radiation and Nuclear Protection Delivery Team (CBRN DT), from hereon in referred to as the Authority, is responsible for the procurement and support of Chemical, Biological, Radiological and Nuclear (CBRN) threat agent Detection, Identification and Monitoring (DIM) and Sample Collection (SC) equipment used within the UK military. 
      
      The Authority has a requirement to provide In-Service Support (ISS) and additional procurement of Capital equipment's for the Reconnaissance and Exploitation Team (RET) capability.  This capability is comprised of multiple teams of specialist military personnel using a broad range of CBRN DIM and SC equipment.  RET is an amalgamation of previously separate capabilities, namely "Light Role Team (LRT)" and "Sampling and Identification of Biological, Chemical and Radiological Agents (SIBCRA)".  RET also includes a specialist drilling capability known as "Monica". The Authority is seeking  a Prime Contractor to be responsible for the requirement. All RET equipment is in-service and has NSN's which will be provided within the ITT. A Prime Contractor shall be required to manage  the full  suite of equipment through a supply chain. No new equipment enhancements  to the RET equipment's are required however additional purchases of current equipment will be needed, the service to be provided and the spares required shall be 'like for like' as per the current requirement.   
      
      RET ISS is defined by a range of specialised DIM and SC equipment which will be stated within a future Invitation To Tender (ITT) and will require the provision of following services including but not limited to;
      
      Contract Management and Service Core Support.
      Equipment Calibration and Planned Maintenance.
      Equipment Survey and Unplanned Maintenance and Repair.
      Supply of Capital Equipment.
      Supply of Capital and Consumable Spares.
      Technical Support Services.
      Post Design Services.
      DSAT compliant training packages
      
      There will be a requirement to operate this contract from a List X facility, therefore if not already List X you will be expected to achieve this accreditation by 31 October 2019.

Title: Provision of L3 Certificate in emergency response ambulance driving ( LS CERAD)
Description:
The University of Cumbria has been actively developing students to HCPC registration as Paramedics for a number of years.  We are successfully growing the existing pre-hospital medicine academic offering and have long term contracts in place with NHS ambulance services, and all branches of the military.
      
      We are currently developing a cohort of twenty (20) Military Medical Technicians, who will qualify as Paramedics in October 2019.  Subsequently they will require a driving qualification which will afford them the opportunity to work in an NHS Ambulance environment.  
      
      The contract will also cover future cohorts requiring training within the contract period.
      
      Therefore, we seek to procure the services of a training organisation who can provide L3 Certificate in Emergency Response Ambulance Driving as set out in the Future Quals (accrediting body) standards, or equivalent and recognised by HCPC.

Title: The Supply of Medical Packaging
Description:
Team Leidos are proud to be delivering the Logistics Commodities and Services Transformation (LCS (T)) Delivery partner Contracts (LCS (T)/0001 dated 16.4.2015) on behalf of the UK Ministry of Defence (the "Prime Contract"). Delivery of other parts of the LCS(T) contract are delivered by Leidos Europe Limited (LEL) and other partners (together "Team Leidos"). 

Team Leidos would like to make interested suppliers aware that it intends to tender for the Supply of Medical Packaging later in the year, with a view to awarding one or more Contracts that will commence during 2020 for a period of up to 4 years. 

The requirement is to supply ruggedized packaging for the safe transportation and storage of Medical Equipment and Ancillaries in the military environment. This extends to the requirement for bespoke padding to fit the dimensions of the equipment and ancillaries that are being transported and stored. The scope may also include the requirement of suitable packaging for the movement of temperature sensitive medical products in the military supply chain.

Team Leidos wishes to stimulate interest, information and views across the market for the fulfilment of this requirement via this PIN.

This Prior Information Notice is not a means to submit a formal expression of interest in respect of any potential tender. Any resultant requirement will be subject to the EU Public Procurement Regulations and respective advertising action.

For further information, please contact Konstantin.Nikolov100@teamleidos.mod.uk

Title: Packaging for the safe transportation and storage of Medical Equipment and Ancillaries - RFI
Description:
Background 
In April 2015, the MOD signed a contract with Leidos Europe Ltd to provide the procurement and inventory management of commodity items (as well as the storage and distribution services) historically provided in-house by the Logistic Commodities and Services Operating Centre. Leidos, working with the MOD, will transform the way these services are delivered to ensure requirements continue to be met whilst providing best value for money for the department. The organisation delivering these services is known as Team Leidos.

Future Arrangements
Team Leidos would like to make interested suppliers aware that it is considering a potential requirement for the Supply of ruggedized packaging cases for the safe transportation and storage of Medical Equipment and Ancillaries in the military environment.  The scope may also include the requirement of suitable packaging for the movement of temperature sensitive medical consumables, medicinal products, blood and blood products,  in the military supply chain.

Process
Team Leidos wishes to stimulate interest, information and views across the market for the supply of this requirement via this Request for Information (RFI).

We do not require pricing at this stage, we are only interested to know which products, if any, you are able to supply.  

Team Leidos is seeking feedback from suppliers regrading capabilities and would be grateful if you could answer the attached questions.

Title: Between Land & Sea Interpretation Project
Description:
Sefton Council are seeking a highly creative agency to deliver a full interpretive project over 2 key locations in Southport, Merseyside. 
This project is part of the wider Maritime, Military & Industrial Heritage of the Atlantic Coast (MMIAH) project to be delivered by The Liverpool City Region Local Enterprise Partnership (LEP). The project will be jointly funded as part of this Interreg Atlantic Area project.  
The initiative is financed by the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), and is designed to address the loss of identity of the coastal towns of the Atlantic Area. The project is specifically concerned with those parts of the area that are rich in their maritime, military and industrial heritage.

Title: MINERVA Man Overboard Detection System
Description:
Defence Equipment & Support is responsible for procuring and supporting the equipment and services for the UK's Armed Forces. The DE&S Future Capabilities Group (FCG) (Formerly Technology Office) improves delivery of Military capability through innovation and exploitation of technology.
      
      The FCG seeks to understand industry readiness and capability to provide Military /Commercial Off the Shelf (MOTS/COTS) and near off the shelf Man Overboard (MOB) Detection System. The response to this request will be used for information purposes only to scope the potential multi-year MINERVA programme.

Title: Aviation Support to BATUK including MEDEVAC, Range Clearance and General Aviation Support Activities
Description:
Air transport services. British Army Training Unit Kenya (BATUK) is responsible for providing training for the British Army and other forces to prepare units and battle groups for operations. BATUK is based out of Nanyuki, to the north of Nairobi, however training takes place in geographically dislocated areas, normally within 200km of the town, and occasionally beyond. An urgent requirement has been identified for the provision of aviation support to BATUK in the form of Medical Evacuation (MEDEVAC) and Range Clearance services and General Aviation Support Activities.
BATUK requires a capability to MEDEVAC injured or ill service personnel, their dependants, employees of BATUK and other entitled personnel from point of injury to the nearest landing site an appropriate medical treatment facility, which is generally in Nairobi. This service is required to be available 24/7 on a 365 day basis, i.e. the service provider must be able to operate by day and by night in low light conditions.
BATUK require a capability to ensure that the training and range areas are clear of humans, livestock and wildlife prior to military exercises taking place . This will involve carrying UK MOD personnel as part of the crew and may involve landing in the training areas as part of the role. This activity has to take place concurrently with the MEDEVAC requirement.
BATUK require a capability to undertake General Aviation Support Activities which includes limited troop movements (including VIP movements), liaison and communication flying in support of Exercises and visits to BATUK. This support would be of secondary importance to the MEDEVAC and Range Clearance roles.
This PIN is issued to offer interested parties the opportunity to discuss this potential requirement, gauge industry appetite and to give industry prior notice that the MOD's intention is to undertake a competitive tender exercise in the near future, with a view to appointing one or more suppliers to provide part or all of the required services, for a period of at least 24 months.
The Authority would like to invite all interested parties to an Industry Engagement Day to be held in Kenya on Wednesday 17th February 2016. This will be an opportunity for us to discuss our potential requirements with you in more detail, seeking your input as to feasibility and achievability.
For further information and to confirm a place at the Industry Engagement Day please email the Commercial Officer leading with this potential procurement ARTD-PD2b1@mod.uk no later than midday on Friday 12th February 2016. If you are unable to attend the event but would like to receive a summary of the discussions, please also make this request by email.
The Authority will not reimburse any costs incurred by any parties who respond to this PIN or who attend the Industry Engagement Day.

Title: NATO Armaments Ballistic Kernel (NABK) S4 Application and Code Development & Support to UK Equipments
Description: Development of software for military applications. This contract procures the development and maintenance of a suite of high integrity software projects and component products, considered fundamental capability for NATO and support for UK defence equipment programmes. The capabilities delivered include ballistic trajectory calculations, terrain data management and deconfliction, management and use of meterological data, providing coordinate transforms and gross error checks on Fire mission data for a number of UK defence equipment programmes. These capabilities are delivered to the following projects: Operational METGM production at the UK Meteorological Office, Fire Control Battlefield Information System Application (FC BISA), Fire Control Application (FCA) and the Type 26 Global Combat Ship (GCS) Gun Fire Control Systems (GFCS). The following projects that may require these capabilities are Advanced Sound Ranging Programme (ASP), Type 45 Destroyer Gun Fire Control System (GFCS) and the Light Gun (105mm L118) and AS90 (115mm) weapon platforms.

Title: RM4658 L0868; Production of Ebola Medals for Cabinet Office; ITT
Description:
The Cabinet Office (the Authority) seeking to procure medals to pay tribute to the efforts of civilian and military personnel involved in the UK’s response to the widespread outbreak of the Ebola disease in West Africa. The Authority estimates that the production of approximately 3500 new medals with be required, to be delivered in tranches. The contract will operate as a call-off arrangement at the agreed fixed unit price per medal.  The Authority requires a fast turnaround of the medals in order to meet a deadline of 1st August 2015 for the first 150 medals. Please see the attached documents for further information.

How to Apply:
To participate in any possible future procurement which results from this Request For Information, Potential Providers must first be registered on the Government Procurement Service e-Sourcing Suite.

If you have not yet registered on the eSourcing Suite, this can be done online at https://gpsesourcing.cabinetoffice.gov.uk by following the link ‘Register for CCS eSourcing’. 

Please note that, to register, you must have a valid DUNS number (as provided by Dun and Bradstreet) for the organisation which you are registering, who will be entering into a contract if invited to do so at the Invitation to Tender stage. 

Full instructions for registration and use of the system can be found at
http://ccs.cabinetoffice.gov.uk/i-am-supplier/respond-tender 


Once you have registered on the e-Sourcing Suite, you will need to express an interest for the RM4658 L0868 Production of Ebola Medals for the Cabinet Office. This is done by emailing ExpressionOfInterest@crowncommercial.gov.uk.
Your email must clearly state: 

•	the name of this procurement: “RM4658 L0868 Production of Ebola Medals for the Cabinet Office”
•	the name of the registered supplier; and 
•	the name and contact details for the registered individual sending the email. 

Crown Commercial Service will then process this email and assign your organisation to the opportunity. The registered user will receive a notification email to alert them once this has been done.

The Invitation to Tender will be issued by close of play on 30/04/2015 and therefore suppliers can register on the e-Sourcing Suite between the issue date of this Contracts Finder advert and the deadline date. 

The deadline date for submission of proposals will be 20th May 2015 at 17:00.

It is advised however that Potential Providers register as soon as practically possible in order to receive the Invitation to Tender and have a sufficient amount of time to respond. 

For technical assistance on use of the e-Sourcing Suite please contact the 
Helpdesk: 
Freephone: 0345 010 3503
Email: supplier@crowncommercial.gov.uk 

Please note that due to the commercially sensitive nature of some of the information enclosed in Appendix B, Potential Providers will need to submit a fully signed Appendix E – Non-Disclosure Agreement before being granted access to the full version.

Title: Materiel Strategy - Managed Service Provider - Work Package 1 - Project Delivery - Air
Description:
The UK MOD’s Defence Equipment and Support (DE&S) organisation has a requirement to appoint a number of Managed Service Providers (MSPs) to transform and improve the operation of its project delivery. For this requirement project delivery is used to describe the totality of the products and services that DE&S delivers to MOD, be it procuring new military equipment, commodities and services, supporting in-service equipment through-life or managing global logistic operations. 

This requirement is part of the DE&S’s wider Materiel Strategy change programme. Under the change programme, the DE&S organisation has been established as a Bespoke Central Government Trading Entity within the public sector from 1 April 2014, with new management freedoms and controls that are appropriate to its challenges and the specialist nature of its business.

Title: Very Light Rail Vehicle (VLR) Project
Description:
The University of Warwick Warwick Manufacturing Group has the following project requirement.

This project involves the design of two identical bogies for a railcar. Each bogie has its own self-contained series-hybrid drive system. Construction of a full railcar demonstrator is the final deliverable of the project. At this stage in the project we require a single bogie solution, i.e. a single engine, single generator, single energy storage system and two traction motors.

Operation of railway vehicles over a wide network in varying environmental conditions creates a harsh operating situation and reliability of components is a priority. Therefore, we require the supplier to have a proven record of accomplishment in the design, development, and construction of generators and resulting generator-set for mobile applications that operate in harsh environments. Such environments include continuous vibration of varying intensity; high vertical acceleration loads (up to 100g); diverse weather conditions such as high winds, snow, severe temperature variation, and wet conditions; and severe restrictions on electromagnetic interference. Vehicles that encounter these operating conditions may be found in the military or aerospace sector in addition to the railway industry.

This tender comprises of three lots;
•	Lot 1 Supply of 1 Generator/Starter and Assembly of a Diesel Engine Generator-Set
•	Lot 2 Supply of a Direct-Drive Traction Package Consisting of 2 Motors
•	Lot 3 Supply of Batteries and Battery Management System and Integration into an Energy Storage System

This is an BELOW EU threshold tender 

All correspondence regarding this tender procedure should be made through the University of Warwick In-Tend system (https://in-tendhost.co.uk/universityofwarwick) via the “Correspondence” functionality. Failure to do so may result in the correspondence being excluded from the tender procedure.

After expressing an interest in this project you will be able to download the full tender document set within 24 hours.

All bids must be received by midday 14/07/15.
Additional Text:
Please refer to http://in-tendhost.co.uk/universityofwarwick for further information. You will be able to download the full tender documents from this site. Any queries in relation to this requirement should be directed to the University of Warwick via the correspondence functionality of our e-tendering system. Failure to do so may result in queries being excluded from the procedure.

Title: Supply & Delivery of Musical Instruments,Technical Equipment Related Supplies & Services, Associated Repairs & the Supply of Sheet Music
Description: Musical instruments and parts. Musical instruments. Repair and maintenance services of musical instruments. Musical instruments and parts. Musical instruments. Repair and maintenance services of musical instruments. The Authority has a requirement for the supply and delivery of Musical Instruments, spares, consumables and associated products,sheet music and the Repair of musical instruments. The requirement will service the various musical bands and schools within the UK Armed Forces based both in the UK and overseas. It is intended to award a maximum number of eighty Enabling Contracts with various suppliers for generic groups of musical instruments and repair services. These generic groups are likely to include but not be limited to sound engineering equipment and technical support(also repair); percussion (also repair); woodwind (also repair); brass (also repair); fretted & electrical (also repair); string (also repair); bagpipes (also repair); miscellaneous (also repair); electrical packages (also repair); pianos (also repair); lighting engineering equipment (also repair); musical instruments for military schools (also repair); and the repair of musical instruments. The Authority reserves the right however to amend the number of groups and the content of the groupings prior to the Invitations to Tender being issued. It is likely that the Invitation to Tender will not include a definitive specification, but will ask potential suppliers to provide maximum price lists of Catalogues currently provided to the general public by bidders, with percentage discount figures detailed, while detailing a maximum man hour rate for their repair charges. The Authority's intention is that MOD customers will be able to approach all participating suppliers within the specific generic heading of the multi-participant framework agreement using mini-competitions. Orders will then be placed with the Contractor offering best value for money to the Authority, taking into account the award criteria detailed in our Invitation to Tender that will refer to this. Interested suppliers should express their interest only at this stage by forwarding their notification of interest to us with their full address, contact name, telephone number and email address. A Pre-Qualification Questionnaire (PQQ) may be issued to interested parties though the Authority reserves the right to proceed to the Invitation to Tender stage without conducting a PQQ. All payments will only be made by the Government Procurement Card (GPC), therefore Tenderers must be VISA enabled by the contract commencement date if they are to receive a contract award. For repair requirements the supplier must be a member of the Association of Musical Instrument Repairers (NAMIR) Ltd or equivalent

Title: External Support for DARA
Description:
The MOD Director Audit, Risk and Assurance has a requirement for external support in the following areas: 

Internal Control and Assurance Frameworks: External support is required to develop control frameworks covering all functional areas (key areas are: finance, commercial, civilian and military personnel, logistics, acquisition, security and business resilience) and business units (Army, Navy, Air, JFC, DIO, HOCS and DE&S). The development of control frameworks will include assessment of key risks, design of controls and assurance strategies for controls. It is envisaged that the external support provider will assess the control design effectiveness and based on their experience offer a view on best practice controls. Assistance will include the implementation of the control frameworks in the organisation units and implementation of assurance strategies. 

2.Enterprise Risk Management Framework: External support is required in implement a common risk framework through out the organisation. This requires working with senior management in the identification and assessment of risks and devising appropriate risk management strategies. Further, support is required to embed risk management in business operations and to improve the quality of risk information including the development of MOD wide risk landscape. Assistance may also be sought in the selection and implementation of a risk software tool.

Fraud: External support is required in undertaking in fraud risk assessments, development of data and investigations.

Title: GB-UK: Fuels and Lubricants; Reducing Cost of Ownership
Description:
THIS IS AN SBRI CHALLENGE DETAILS CAN BE VIEWED ON THE INNOVATE UK WEBSITE. THIS NOTICE IS A DUPLICATE TO GAIN FULL COVERAGE.
Up to £1M is available for Phase 1 of this 2 phase competition funded by MOD.
The DE&S shall "equip & support our Armed Forces for operations now & in the future." DE&S is responsible for procuring & supporting all the equipment & services for the UK Armed Forces.To operate in harsh hostile & toxic environments whilst maintaining operational effectiveness is a challenge.The aim is to provide fit, form & function.Provide the user with IPE that is comfortable to wear ensuring the user can operate safely effectively & efficiently; whether on land sea or air (or a combination). The E-IPE challenge is to improve user effectiveness through a coherent & integrated clothing &protection system & bidders are to focus on 1 or more of the 7 key themes:
 •CBRN Protection – low burden,broad spectrum respiratory & dermal protection against toxic vapours,liquids & aerosols via integration with existing operational equipment
•Climatic/Environmental Protection – for integration of protective clothing against extremes of hot & cold e.g. on the upper deck of a carrier 
•Fire Protection – enhanced level of protection & reduction of the thermo physiological burden of the fire protection on board ships/carriers
•Industrial Protection – for personnel against for example hazardous materials or substances,noise etc 
•Blunt & Ballistic Protection–for integration of protective material into clothing without affecting the human factors(bulk,thermal burden,range of movement) 
•Enhanced Hand Protection–increase the capability/interoperability of gloves whilst providing increased functionality eg touch screen capability
•Novel Fitting Techniques – enable accurate measuring of the user for IPE to improve accuracy of armour positioning & optimise the sizing/fit.
The user needs a range of IPE that requires integration with other equipment. Innovative methods of integration of IPE would be beneficial to reduce the equipment burden on the user improve interoperability & potentially reduce inventory holdings.
The results assist DE&S to de-risk procurement & have broad exploitation for various specialist military users/industry/ civil/international markets.
Phase 1 therefore seeks proposals for proof of concept research into innovative technologies, materials/designs that optimise IPE deployed today in harsh, hostile & toxic environments.  
Phase 2 funding to develop working prototypes will be available for those projects that demo the greatest potential at the end of the Phase 1 contract.
This comp opens  1 Jun - closes at 12 noon on 29 Jul 15.
A briefing event in London on 14 Jul 15.
The London event is oversubscribed.A Briefing webinar will be held 17 Jul at 2pm.
Register for the webinar here.
All proposals must be submitted via the Innovate UK Portal. 
The comp is run by Innovate UK. 
Registration end 22 Jul 15
Closes 29 Jul 15
Additional Text:
The contracting authority considers that this contract may be suitable for economic operators that are small or medium enterprises (SMEs). However, any selection of tenderers will be based solely on the criteria set out for the procurement, and the contract will be awarded on the basis of the most economically advantageous tender.
Electronic Trading; Potential suppliers must note the mandatory requirement for electronic trading using the Ministry of Defence's standard Purchase to Payment (P2P) system operating under the Defence Electronic Commerce Service, which shall be a special condition for performance of this contract. You can find details on the P2P system at www.d2btrade.com. The contractor shall be required to sign DEFFORM 30 (Electronic Transaction Agreements) and unconditionally accept DEFCON 5J (Unique Identifiers), DEFCON 129J (The Use of Electronic Business Delivery Form) and DEFCON 522J (Payment Under P2P).

Title: GB-ANDOVER: ARTDIPT/088 PROVISION OF AIRMANSHIP DEVELOPMENT FLYING FOR ARMY’S TACTICAL UNMANNED AIR SYSTEMS PERSONNEL
Description:
The Army has identified a requirement to procure the services of a Flight Training Organisation to provide live flying training to develop airmanship and an awareness of the air environment for service personnel as part of their progressive training to operate the Watchkeeper (WK) Unmanned Air Systems (UAS).  

Training will be required for up to 38 students (depending on course uptake) from contract award (estimated Sep 15) to March 2016.   The majority of students will be experienced Unmanned Air System pilots who will benefit from additional in-cockpit experience to assist in enhancing their airmanship.  Suitably qualified and experienced instructors will be required to provide instruction and assessment during a series of 8 sorties for each student (totalling approximately 9 ½ hours of flying) in accordance with the Authority’s Course Training Package.  Training is aimed at providing the student with ground and air instruction, including the following areas: flight planning and briefing; experiencing how an aircraft handles in straight and level flight, climbing descending and turning and during take off and landing; interaction with Air Traffic Control and use of radio communications; navigation; crew management; decision making and dealing with emergencies (threat and error management).   

Instructors will need to be suitably qualified in accordance with CAA regulations and it is desirable that they will have previous military flying experience and have been a Central Flying School endorsed instructor.  Army Aviation Standards organisation will review training delivery in order to assure the Authority that the correct level of instruction will be provided. 

The Flight Training Organisation will be expected to offer training within a 60 minute travel time by road from Larkhill, Wiltshire.  Training will be required during normal working hours, Monday to Friday.  Close liaison with the Authority will be required to provide aircraft/instructor availability and a flying forecast to enable the most efficient use of students’ time. Suitable on-site briefing facilities to conduct planning should be available, together with provision of MET , NOTAM and associated maps and publications.   Students should be provided with a colour moving map display for each sortie – either as part of the aircraft equipment or as a GPS enabled tablet cleared for use in the cockpit – this represents the method that students will ultimately plan and conduct flights.
Contact Address 1: HQ ARTD, Trenchard Lines, Upavon, Pewsey, Wilts,

Title: Consultant for Air Show June 2016
Description: THE PROCUREMENT DOCUMENTS BELOW ARE READ ONLY. DO NOT USE THEM TO COMPLETE AND SUBMIT TENDER.  PLEASE REGISTER YOUR INTEREST TO ACCESS THE PROCUREMENT DOCUMENTS TO COMPLETE AND SUBMIT. ONLY APPLICANTS WHO HAVE REGISTERED AN INTEREST WILL RECEIVE UPDATE NOTIFICATIONS.   The Authority is seeking an experienced Air Show Consultant with a proven track record to deliver a minimum two (2) day Air Show Event in Torbay over a weekend in June 2016. It is intended that the Consultant will provide a continuous flying programme to include military and civilian aircraft, parachute display teams and, if possible, international attractions within the agreed budget.  The Authority has secured a start up fund of £60,000 from the Coastal Communities Fund. This funding must bring in at least five million pounds (£5,000,000) in new business and spending to the economy of Torbay through the event. The event must be sustainable year after year. The balance of the funding is being raised through sponsorship which is the subject of a separate procurement process.  The event is expected to be supported by at least 150,000 visitors across the two days of the event and, if similar to Weston-Super-Mare, Bournemouth, Dawlish and Eastbourne Air Shows, attendance could be much higher. The Air Show is expected to be the largest event delivered in Torbay in terms of visitor numbers in recent years.

Title: DFID 7293 Burma Enterprise Opportunity Facility
Description:
Actual CPV code is ‘75211200 Foreign Economic-Aid Related Services’.

DFID aims to help create a better governed, more peaceful & prosperous Burma that uses its increased wealth to reduce poverty and vulnerability, and build the human capability to take up opportunities within Burma and the region more broadly. Economic development is a major part of DFID’s offer in Burma as reflected in DFID Burma’s Operational Plan up to March 2016. Burma’s transition away from a military government has been accompanied by some economic reform. This has the potential to launch an economic transformation in Burma that could underpin sustainable poverty reduction by increasing productivity in agricultural, industrial and service sectors, and through movements of labour from lower productivity work to higher productivity work. To achieve this, Burma will need to reform across a range of areas. As part of DFID’s efforts to help reform in these areas, DFID has developed a new business case, ‘Business for Shared Prosperity in Burma’, for work up to 31 December 2020. This programme aims to improve economic opportunities for poor people in Burma by unlocking the potential of business by working in five areas: The regulatory and institutional environment for doing business; Financial sector; Infrastructure – financing and policy; Trade; and Inclusion and responsible business. DFID wishes to seek the services of a supplier to implement one of the delivery mechanisms of the Business Case, the Burma Enterprise Opportunity Facility. The facility will have two primary roles: provision of advice, technical assistance and capacity building; and issuing calls for proposals for innovative new projects that contribute to the objectives of the programme. We also envisage it will have a secondary role of assuming programme management on behalf of DFID for the Myanmar Centre for Responsible Business. DFID expects the supplier to be in place by the 1st of April at the latest and the contract will last until December 2020, with a 6 month inception phase. There will be two break points in the programme, one after the inception phase and one at the point of the third annual review in August 2018. At these break points, DFID reserves the right to stop, scale up or re-contract the facility. This is a Competitive Procedure with Negotiation as the nature of the services cannot be established with sufficient precision to permit the award of the contract using the Open or Restricted procedure. After evaluation of the submitted pre-qualification questionnaire, a minimum of 3 and maximum of 6 suppliers will then be invited to tender. A further shortlisted group of suppliers will then be invited to negotiation.
Additional Text:
All relevant information relating to this Contract Notice can be found on the DFID Supplier Portal where suppliers can register their interest directly.

If you are not already registered as a supplier on the DFID Supplier Portal please follow the guidance which can be found on the top left of the home page: https://supplierportal.dfid.gov.uk/selfservice/

Title: Provision of Policing Skills Support to the Iraq Historic Allegations Team (IHAT)
Description:
The MOD has a requirement for an investigative capability to work in support of the Royal Navy Police (RNP) within the Iraq Historic Allegations Team (IHAT).  The IHAT is based in Upavon, Wiltshire.  It is responsible for the investigation of allegations arising from British military operations in Iraq between 2003 and 2009.  It operates within the statutory framework of the Armed Forces Act 2006 and all investigative activity is carried out under the day to day supervision and control of the Director IHAT and the Senior RNP Officer.

The contractor must be able to provide a large number (circa 127) of suitably qualified and experienced personnel to support the RNP across a range of specialist policing functions and roles.  Their tasks will include: the interviewing of witnesses, casework research and analysis, the running of a Major Incident Room and carrying out forensic analysis.  Some of the contractor's personnel will also be required to fill management roles within IHAT and to assist in the development of investigative strategies.
Contact Address 1: Army HQ Commercial Procurement Team B

Title: Broxhead House Business Enterprise Centre Capital Works, Bordon
Description:
The Homes & Communities Agency (HCA) is seeking a Contractor to refurbish an existing building for use as a new Business and Enterprise Centre (BEC) in Whitehill and Bordon, Hampshire on a site formerly known as Louisburg Barracks.

Once refurbished, the Victorian military building will offer:
Circa 1500 m2 of GIA, providing approximately 900 m2 of net-lettable office floorspace, 
A new-build visitor entrance and reception area,
Meeting rooms, conference and event facilities, 
Virtual office services for home-based businesses 
A business lounge with hot-desking and Wi-Fi
Adequate parking
The work comprises, but is not limited to the following:
Demolition of low grade extensions
Minor structural alterations
Extensive building refurbishment and decoration
Renewed Building Services
Construction of extensions
External works and Landscaping
Infrastructure works within property boundary 
The above works will be procured through a single Contractor, rather than individual packages for respective trades/disciplines. Procurement of an Operator for the completed Business Enterprise Centre is not part of this notice.

Procurement will be via single stage traditional route, utilising JCT Form of Contract without quantities.  Firms wishing to tender should download all documentation and return by the deadline given.
It is envisaged that work will commence early January 2016.

The completion of the roof works will be subject to Sectional Completion, full details of which will be contained within the Tender Documentation.

Title: FOR THE PROVISION OF PHEC CLINICAL  PLACEMENTS FOR COHORT 2 OF DEFENCE MEDIC (DM) PROGRAMME DELIVERED BY DCHET
Description:
For the provision of up to 47 Ambulance Clinical Placements with NHS Ambulance Trusts. Health Education England (HEE) is mandated  by the Government to work with the MOD ‘to enhance the existing capability of the Defence Medical Service either through up-skilling of the existing workforce or by supporting the training of new entrants’.  An EMT award is considered by HEE and the DMS to be most appropriate and is achieved through an 8 week didactic course and 750 hours (20 wks) of clinical practice placements, of which not less than 15wks must be in a Pre-Hospital Emergency Care (PHEC) setting. There are no suitable military units in which to conduct the PHEC clinical practice placements, so these will have to be undertaken within Ambulance Trusts.  In order for Defence Medics to access training placements within every Ambulance Trust, they must have a level of competence acceptable to them all.  Access to ambulance placements will be achieved through a top level agreement with Health Education England and the Association of Ambulance Chief Executives (AACE) who will liaise and broker placements with the individual Ambulance Trusts across the UK  
in support of the new Defence Medic programme.

Title: External Support: Risk, Internal Control & Assurance Functions for DARA
Description:
The MoD Director Audit, Risk and Assurance had a requirement for external support in the following areas:
1.	Internal Control and Assurance Frameworks:  External support is required to develop control frameworks covering all functional areas (key areas were: finance, commercial, civilian and military personnel, logistics, acquisition, security and business resilience) and business units (Army, Navy, Air, JFC, DIO, HOCS and DE&S).  The development of control frameworks will include assessment of key risks, design of controls and assurance strategies for controls.  It was envisaged that the external support provider will assess the control design effectiveness and based on their experience offer a view on best practice controls.  Assistance will include the implementation of the control frameworks in the organisation units and implementation of assurance strategies.
2.	Enterprise Risk Management Framework:  External support is required to implement a common risk framework throughout the organisation.  This requires working with senior management in the identification and assessment of risks and devising appropriate risk management strategies.  Further, support is required to embed risk management in business operations and to improve the quality of risk information including the development of MoD wide risk landscape.  Assistance may also be sought in the selection and implementation of a risk software tool.
3.	Fraud:  External support is required in undertaking in fraud risk assessments, development of data and investigations.

Title: UK Aeronautical Terrain and Obstacle Data Repository (UK ATODR)
Description:
The CAA has a potential requirement for the mapping of Terrain and Obstacle Data within the UK.

The introduction of Standards and Recommended Practices (SARP’s) by ICAO into Annex 15, Aeronautical Information Services” (AIS), Chapter 10 – Electronic Terrain and Obstacle Data (eTOD), requires the provision of terrain and obstacle data within the entire State (UK FIR) as digital data sets. The eTOD requirements deal with the electronic terrain and obstacle data function, coverage, terrain and obstacle numerical requirements, content and structure of terrain and obstacle databases, product specifications for terrain and obstacle data and their availability.

The UK currently utilises obstacle data collected and maintained by the Defence Geographic Centre (DGC), Ministry of Defence, for the purpose of publishing En-Route obstacle data in the UK AIP ENR 5.4. a DVOF data update is provided on a monthly basis to the UK AIS service provider, National Air Traffic Services (NATS).  

As obstacle and terrain data is of strategic benefit to both civil and military aviation, the CAA and MoD are seeking to establish a joint means for the collection of terrain and obstacle data and ongoing maintenance.    

With a potential contract award value in excess of OJEU levels, requiring a tender process, it is necessary that a market test exercise is undertaken to determine if there are suitable organisations that have the surveying resource and technological capability to fulfil the UK’s ATODR requirements.

To assist in this matter, we are intending to hold a Bidder Market Engagement Day - see II.7 Additional Information for details.
