Title: Very Light Rail Vehicle (VLR) Project - AWARD
Description:
The University of Warwick Warwick Manufacturing Group has the following project requirement.

This project involves the design of two identical bogies for a railcar. Each bogie has its own self-contained series-hybrid drive system. Construction of a full railcar demonstrator is the final deliverable of the project. At this stage in the project we require a single bogie solution, i.e. a single engine, single generator, single energy storage system and two traction motors.

Operation of railway vehicles over a wide network in varying environmental conditions creates a harsh operating situation and reliability of components is a priority. Therefore, we require the supplier to have a proven record of accomplishment in the design, development, and construction of generators and resulting generator-set for mobile applications that operate in harsh environments. Such environments include continuous vibration of varying intensity; high vertical acceleration loads (up to 100g); diverse weather conditions such as high winds, snow, severe temperature variation, and wet conditions; and severe restrictions on electromagnetic interference. Vehicles that encounter these operating conditions may be found in the military or aerospace sector in addition to the railway industry.

This tender comprises of three lots;
•	Lot 1 Supply of 1 Generator/Starter and Assembly of a Diesel Engine Generator-Set
•	Lot 2 Supply of a Direct-Drive Traction Package Consisting of 2 Motors
•	Lot 3 Supply of Batteries and Battery Management System and Integration into an Energy Storage System

This is an BELOW EU threshold tender 

All correspondence regarding this tender procedure should be made through the University of Warwick In-Tend system (https://in-tendhost.co.uk/universityofwarwick) via the “Correspondence” functionality. Failure to do so may result in the correspondence being excluded from the tender procedure.

After expressing an interest in this project you will be able to download the full tender document set within 24 hours.

All bids must be received by midday 14/07/15.

Title: Provision of Policing Skills Support to the Iraq Historic Allegations Team (IHAT)
Description:
The MOD has a requirement for an investigative capability to work in support of the Royal Navy Police (RNP) within the Iraq Historic Allegations Team (IHAT). The IHAT is based in Upavon, Wiltshire.  It is responsible for the investigation of allegations arising from British military operations in Iraq between 2003 and 2009.  It operates within the statutory framework of the Armed Forces Act 2006 and all investigative activity is carried out under the day to day supervision and control of the Director IHAT and the Senior RNP Officer.
The contractor must be able to provide a large number (circa 127) of suitably qualified and experienced personnel to support the RNP across a range of specialist policing functions and roles.  Their tasks will include: the interviewing of witnesses, casework research and analysis, the running of a Major Incident Room and carrying out forensic analysis.  Some of the contractor's personnel will also be required to fill management roles within IHAT and to assist in the development of investigative strategies.

Title: 7253 A national planning overview of 19th century forts and associated fortifications
Description:
19th century forts and associated fortifications are some of our coast’s most distinctive monuments.  Architecturally and topographically they are striking places with clear historic significance often dominating their settings and localities.  They embody the changing nature of 19th century conflict as the technology of the industrial age was applied to warfare, fuelling great rivalry between Europe’s imperial powers.

Militarily most 19th century forts were declared obsolete in 1956, subsequently a number have been preserved as visitor attractions by English Heritage and other organisations.  A number have remained with the Ministry of Defence.  Others have been converted to residential and commercial uses, whilst others are derelict subject to decay and vandalism, and are registered as Heritage at Risk.

To ensure that more of these forts find new uses imaginative schemes based on best constructive conservation practices are required.  Increasingly, proposals are being put forward to convert forts to new uses; potentially involving some loss of historic fabric and later defensive features.  Forts are especially vulnerable to harm to their significance by virtue of changes to their settings.

This project is designed to provide a national overview of 19th century forts and associated fortifications in England.  It will identify which ones best exemplify evolution of military architecture, retain the best examples of features and fittings of various dates, and discuss the relative significance of later rearmament phases.  
The report will help to inform the work of Historic England and others to ensure well-informed and nationally consistent advice is available to those promoting and managing change, as well as would be developers.

Title: CB/BFG/0108 Provision of Bulk Fuel Carrying Vehicle Testing, Certification & Repair British Forces Germany
Description: Provision of Bulk Fuel Carrying Vehicle Testing, Certification & Repair of fuel dispensing/fluid systems fitted to British Forces Germany military vehicles.  The ADR (Accord European Relatif au Transport International du Merchandis Dangereuses par Route (European Agreement Concerning the International Carriage of Dangerous Goods by Road)) requires Fuel Vehicles to be subjected to elapsed time Intermediate (Leakproof) and Periodic (Hydraulic) examinations.  These are to be conducted by Examination Bodies accredited by the Competent Body of the EU country in which the vehicle or equipment is operating (in this instance, TüV Germany).  In addition to the periodic testing it also defines the requirement and safety precautions for gas freeing, tank cleaning, changing of grade/product and fuel vehicle tank repair.  Compliance with the European Regulations is mandated for the operation of all Ministry Of Defence fuel carrying vehicles.

orgName: Ministry of Defence, Air Support, C17 Command Support and Airborne Equipment Project Team (CSAE PT)
Title: Parachute Equipment Support Contract
Description:
The UK Ministry of Defence (MOD) is committed to ensuring the ongoing safety and airworthiness of a suite of parachutes and associated equipment on a ‘first time, every time’ basis. MOD has a requirement to support parachuting via a range of maintenance and logistics services, including but not limited to the configuration management, maintenance, repair, inventory management, storage, modification, packing and checking of a range of parachutes and parachuting equipment.
This requirement is for circa 60,000 repairs, packing instances, checks, etc. of Airborne Forces Equipment (to support personnel parachuting) and Airborne Delivery Equipment (to support stores drops) in total per annum. This is flexible, as is the range of parachutes supported. Other services such as support to exercises at Main and Forward Operating bases may also be required.
It is anticipated that the solution will run from April 2017 to 2023.
MOD C17CSAE Project Team intend to invite to tender only those parties who are accredited to or capable of being accredited to BS EN ISO 9001  and Military Aviation Authority MAOS (Maintenance Approved Organisation Scheme) standards.

Title: Provision of Defence Medic PHEC/Acute Trauma Placements
Description: The requirement is for the provision of Pre Hospital Emergency Care placements to facilitate and support Defence Medical Services personnel achieving the mandated Level 4 Associate Ambulance Practitioner Award. The support service provider will provide ambulance placements that can deliver both emergency and routine carework. Mentors within the placement areas to support the trainees and supply expert witness testimony on the individuals competence in order to complete their placement portfolios. Placements for 9 intakes for up to 60 military students per intake will be required over the contract period. The contract period will be 22 February 2016 to 31 March 2018.

Title: Southport Air Show Air Display Management
Description:
The Southport Seafront Air Show is recognised as the North West's largest Air show attracting up to 100,000 spectators over two days in September. It was first held in 1991 and attracts tens of thousands of spectators to see military and civilian aircraft, classic jets, helicopters, aerobatics by the world famous Red Arrows, warbirds and parachute displays take to the skies above Southport.

Combining a spectacular air display with a host of ground activities, the Southport Air show is an exhilarating and fun-filled experience that the whole family can enjoy. 

The event is one of the aviation calendar's most spectacular events, providing stunning views of the best jets, fighters, bombers, helicopters and aerobatic aircraft. 

Sefton Council?s Tourism Section is responsible for arranging the event and is looking for a suitable organisation who can provide a fully managed air show flying display service that is fully compliant with UK Civil Aviation Authority and Ministry of Defence requirements.
Additional Text:
Bidders are requested to submit a quotation proposal ahead of the closing date and time.
Service required to be delivered in the Borough of Sefton Council.

Title: GB-swindon: The design, supply, delivery, and installation of laser safety equipment necessary to create a Laser Controlled Area (LCA)
Description:
NOTE: This notice was updated on 08 February 2016 for the following reason: Additional information concerns EOI1.	The Ministry of Defence (MoD) has a requirement for the design, supply, delivery, and installation of safety equipment necessary to create a Laser Controlled Area (LCA) within one of the laboratory spaces used by the Nuclear Department. 

2.	The Nuclear Department owns a Class 4 Laser which can be used to image water flowing in an acrylic channel. The laser will be operated in the ND Irradiation Facility in a room which is shared with other scientific equipment. To allow simultaneous use of the facility, which is a requirement, a Laser Controlled Area must be established in accordance with JSP 390 – Military Laser Safety.   As this system will be operated in a laboratory environment, the most relevant section is JSP 390 Volume 1 Issue 3 Section 3.

3.	The expected engineered solution is described in paragraph 4 however, other solutions that satisfy the requirements will also be considered.

4.	It is expected that the most cost effective way to establish the LCA is to divide the room into two areas using a laser blocking material which must comply with IEC 60825-4:2006 in the pitched roof space and a curtain, complying to the same specification, hanging below the trusses. The curtain is to be attached at each end to walls by an interlocked connection. Above the curtain, a laser blocking material must be used to fill the spaces between trusses which support the roof. A new interlock system is also required to replace the existing obsolete system.  The new system should allow for a short, timed,  interlock override to allow safe ingress/egress from the area while the laser is functioning (often the laser will need to run continuously for hours at a time to generate data).  In addition, the new interlock should be connected to external signs which indicate the state of the laser to anyone outside the laser controlled area.  Personal Protective Equipment (Eyewear) is also required for 5 people (based on the instructor plus 4 students). 

5.	The MoD will require a full description and “rough” drawing to be submitted at the tender stage to identify the proposed solution and safety functionality.

6.	The Authority envisages a need for a brief site survey to enable potential suppliers to inspect the facility and compile accurate measurements of the installation site. This is planned to take place on 15 Feb 16 13:30.

7.	The Authority has the desire for delivery and installation by the end of Mar 2016

Full details of the requirements for the Supply, Delivery and Installation of Safety Equipment for a Laser Controlled Area (LCA) will be included in the tender documents.

Please note it is MOD policy to make payment via Purchase to Payment (P2P).
Additional Text:
To view this notice, register as a supplier here:

http://www.contracts.mod.uk/delta/signup.html?userType=supplier

and search for the notice with reference 'GB-swindon: The design, supply, delivery, and installation of laser safety equipment necessary to create a Laser Controlled Area (LCA)'.

Title: *FOR TRANSPARENCY ONLY* - MEDICAL EQUIPMENT AIRWORTHINESS TESTING
Description:
For transparency purposes only.

The Medical Delivery Team (Med DT) required six items of medical equipment to be assessed to ensure the safe use of medical equipment on board military aircraft. The assessment, along with an assessment of compliance, is to demonstrate that this equipment conforms to airworthiness and safety requirements and Electro Magnetic Compatibility (‘EMC’) & Environmental Testing. All assessments are required to be carried out against the ‘Generic SPAME v5’ document which outlines the standards required for performing evaluations of this type.

This requirement was competed under the Framework Agreement for Technical Support (FATS) STS franework agreement.

Title: CY-Episkopi: BFCCB/1359 - Provision of Safety Boat for Pyla Ranges
Description:
British Forces Cyprus (the Authority) has a requirement for the Provision of a Safety Boat for Pyla Ranges from 1 April 2016 to 31 March 2021.   

The requirement is for the hire of a safety boat and fully qualified driver to pick up the Military Range Sentry from Romanzo Jetty, Dhekelia for the purpose of clearing and maintaining the Sea Danger Area (SDA) at Pyla Live Firing Tactical Training Area (LFTTA) during training exercises. 


Expressions of Interest (EOI’s) must contain details of your company to include the following information:

EOIs are to be submitted in English, by email, to the following address: DefComrclCC-JFC2a2@mod.uk by the deadline of 12:00 EET on Thur 18th February 2016. 

Potential Suppliers should note that any EOI’s received after this time and date will not be considered.

Title: Chatham Placemaking Project: Detailed Design
Description: Medway Council requires a landscape architecture led consultant team to develop the public realm plans for the priority areas identified in the in-progress Chatham Placemaking, Public Realm and Connectivity Project. The area covered by the Project includes the primary route from Chatham railway station to the Chatham waterfront civic space, encompassing Railway Street and Military Road. The Project also includes the waterfront civic space, stretching from the River Medway and the Waterfront Pumping Station to the bus station, the Paddock and the north-western entrance to the Pentagon shopping centre. Each part of the town sequence from the station to the civic space has its own particular problems requiring its own set of responses. It is proposed that a sequential journey of connected locations and points are used as the means to create a strong narrative and compelling resolution. The proposals are developed up to RIBA Stage 3 and have focused on creating an enticing and accessible journey from the station to the high street, waterfront and beyond. Collectively, the proposals ensure that regeneration benefits the wider community. By creating more public space and facilitating pedestrian movement and activity it is hoped that the proposals will create a more convivial and positive experience of Chatham town centre.

Title: Essex Construction Professional Services Framework Agreement
Description:
Essex County Council (ECC) intends to establish a 4 year Framework Agreement for the provision of Professional Services to support and manage the delivery of major capital construction projects. 

The scope of services are as follows:

Primary Services:
• Cost Management Services
• Project Management Services (including Client CDM duties)
• Framework Management Services

Secondary Services:
• Architectural Services
• Building Services Engineering
• Building Surveying Services
• Structural Engineering Services
• Town Planning Services
• Project Sponsor Services

Ad-hoc Services:
• Acoustic Surveys
• Aboriculture Surveys
• Archaeological Surveys
• Asbestos Surveys
• Condition Surveys (of building services in existing buildings)
• Ecological Surveys
• Electrical Load Testing Services
• Ground Investigations
• Military Ordnance Surveys
• Structural Surveys
• Utilities (mains) Surveys
• Below Ground Services Surveys
• 3D Surveys of Retained Buildings
• Environmental Impact Assessments
• Traffic Surveys & Assessments

The Framework Agreement will be available to other Contracting Authorities within the East of England and is anticipated to be operational by 1st September 2016.
Contact Address 1: Commercial, Essex County Council, County Hall, Market Road

How to express an interest in this tender: Applicants must contact ECC to request to be invited to this tender by following these instructions: 1. Send an email with your organisation name in the subject title field to: email2workspace-prod+ECC+WS631797698+3vp1@ansmtp.ariba.com asking to be invited to this tender and providing your contact name and Supplier ID/User ANID from your Ariba registration details. 2. If you have more than one registered user who you want invited to the event, provide the name(s) of each registered user in your request as it may not be possible to include additional users at a later stage. If you are not registered in Ariba at all, please go to http://ecc.supplier.ariba.com/ad/register/SSOActions?type=full and follow the instructions to register then follow steps 1 and 2 above. Title: Supply of Temporary Demountable Exhibition Showcases
Description:
The National Army Museum is currently undergoing a major refurbishment.  Concurrent with this refurbishment the Museum will be installing a temporary flexible exhibition gallery.  

The Museum wishes to purchase 8 demountable showcases for their Temporary Exhibition Gallery. 

In all instances, it is essential that the Collection (which is of international significance) is displayed sensitively and aesthetically, and that the showcases must provide the visitor with excellent visual access to the displayed content.

The cases will display a broad range of artefacts, including uniforms, medals, textiles, manuscripts, ethnographic objects, fine and decorative art and military kit. Display cases may contain both organic and non-organic materials, and special attention is drawn to the inclusion of non-deactivated Section Five firearms that will require Home Office approved security.
Contact Address 1: National Army Museum Royal Hospital Road
Attachments: 20160211_Brief for the Procurement of Temporary Gallery Showcase_SG.docx Clarifications for Showcases Tender.docx

orgName: Ministry of Defence, Air Support, Air Commodities Project Team (AC PT)
Title: ACCOMM2/7040 - SPARES INCLUSIVE REPAIR Contract PLUS POST DESIGN SERVICES for the Support OF FIRE SUPPRESSION, NUCLEAR BIOLOGICAL CHEMICAL AND INFLATION AIRCRAFT EQUIPMENT
Description:
VOLUNTARY TRANSPARENCY NOTICE - SPARES

SPARES CONTRACT FOR THE SUPPORT OF FIRE SUPPRESSION, NUCLEAR BIOLOGICAL CHEMICAL AND INFLATION AIRCRAFT EQUIPMENT


The Air Commodities Team, part of the UK Ministry of Defence, intends to award a contract extension to Kidde Graviner for the provision of a Support Contract which will contain; Repair, Spares, Post Design Services and Project Management for Kidde Graviner Fire Suppression, Nuclear, Biological, Chemical and Inflation Equipment for a maximum period of 18 months commencing 15 March 2016.

It is considered that this contract can be placed using the negotiated procedure without prior publication of a contract notice pursuant to Article 28(1)(e) of Directive 2009/81/EC (Regulation 16(1)(a)(ii) of the Defence and Security Public Contracts Regulations (DSPCR) of 2011).  This is because Kidde Graviner are the Original Equipment Manufacturer (OEM) and Component Design Organisation for the equipment, and, bespoke tooling, test equipment and technical document sets are only available to Kidde Graviner.  Also, given the airworthiness regulations of the Military Airworthiness Authority (MAA) it would not be possible to ensure that another economic operator could be sufficiently qualified, within the timeframe, to undertake the requirement.  This would then result in the Authority being unable to fulfil safety requirements that must be adhered to, in order to ensure the safe operation of the associated aircraft within an Airworthy environment.  Achieving the required airworthiness standards required in this case, is an extremely complex process, and would mean that the enabling of another economic operator to be able to complete this work would invite substantial risks to the safety and interoperability of parts on multiple aircraft/airborne equipments required for the safe operations of the relevant aircraft.

Title: Provision of Consultancy for the Total Support Force Programme
Description:
The PMO requirement is based upon the ongoing need to seize the opportunities presented through the current and future Defence transformation activities.  The PMO is required to assess the identified capability gaps arising from Army plans, providing solutions and opportunities according to the criteria used, namely; assured military competence, assured technical competence and Value for Defence (VfD)

The TSF concept seeks to fill Army capability gaps with a blend of Regular, Reserve, Sponsored Reserve (SR) and contractors to achieve the mandated output.  This enables a pre-planned force mix to be generated at a lower cost per unit of capability than the previous structure.  As the TSF has matured, additional opportunities to achieve Value for Defence and reduce costs to the Army TLB have been identified and investigated.

Title: RCDS Strategy Exercise and Contracted Support
Description:
The Royal College of Defence Studies (RCDS) is an eleven month post graduate course in international strategic studies, focused upon security, stability and prosperity at the grand strategic level of governmental decisions both nationally and within the international community.  The Members (as students are called), predominantly but not only from military backgrounds, are selected for their potential to reach the highest ranks of senior leadership and advisory posts in their own countries. As part of the core syllabus the RCDS runs two Strategic Exercises exposing its Members to the complexity of strategic analysis and formulation in two stages, enhancing their understanding of the requirements of strategy-making and developing their skills of strategic analysis and policy formulation.  
The requirement is to provide 2 separate but inter-linked exercises designed to exploit the Members’ understanding of the international system, focusing upon but not limited to the themes of international security, stability and prosperity. The exercises should be challenging and stimulating, demanding an examination of major geopolitical issues, regionally and globally in the near term, and provide the opportunity for the Members to engage in realistic and thorough strategic analysis and formulation and for their outputs to be tested in a realistic and developmental fashion.   In both exercises the Members have to demonstrate an understanding of and ability in: strategic analysis and formulation; decision making in a complex, dynamic near-real-time environment; communicating with and influencing other actors; developing and communicating a strategic narrative; operating imaginatively and persuasively under stressful, real-life conditions
The exercises are, in effect, mutually supporting in that they lead the Members, in sequence, through the business of strategic analysis and formulation before testing these against plausible real-world disruptive crisis management catalysts. The essential differences between the two exercises are that the first, Strategy Exercise 1 is a mentor led teaching evolution with a national strategy focus and sequential catalysts providing an initial deliberate and procedural approach to the principles and art of strategy-making. It should provide a coherent thread which can then be further developed throughout the remainder of the course and tested in the second evolution.  Strategy Exercise 2 is a more complex and dynamic member led undertaking requiring a global grand strategy focus with catalysts played concurrently after being introduced. The Exercises and immediate preparation will take place at RCDS, Seaford House, London SW1X 8NS and the filming will take place there, or at the Defence Academy, Shrivenham or RAF Halton.

Title: Provision of a Support Trainer for the LMDP

The Foundation Leadership Management and Development Programme is an 
essential training programme designed to empower and enable first line 
supervisors to lead, manage and develop their staff in line with the organisations 
Mission Statement, Credo and ethos.

Trainers involved in the delivery of the programme are qualified teacher/trainers

experience in the policing and military arenas.

The requirement in this instance is to provide additional trainer support to the 
existing team for the delivery of the Foundation Programme.  Potential candidates 
should be qualified teacher/trainers with proven experience in the delivery of 
leadership and management programmes in a similar environment.

The requirement is to deliver training to 80+ first line supervisors in the current

psychometric feedback using the MBTI, Belbin and Headlight 360 instruments as 
mentioned above.

Title: GB-Bristol: Land Vehicle Exercise (LVEX) SBRI Phase 2-Signature Reduction MOLLE
Description:
LVEx will contribute towards efforts to return to Contingent Operations by identification, prioritisation and evaluation of equipments and concepts designed to improve the Mounted Close Combat (MCC) capability.
This competition is divided into two separate strands. 
1.	COTS - Mature “Commercial off the Shelf” (COTS) equipment, which is ready to be tested in a military context will be considered. 

2.	SBRI - Novel concepts and applications, including COTS offerings currently applied in non-defence areas that require R&D to make them applicable to defence needs are sought in order to provide innovative solutions.

Ultimately this will help MoD to de-risk procurement, generate evidence of capability gaps and inform requirements for future Equipment Programmes.
LVEx 2013 focuses on four key themes. Industry is invited to submit COTS technologies with innovative applications, or concepts that could provide solutions to any or all of the themes:
•	Mobility - We are looking for innovative ways to enhance the mobility of our vehicles over difficult terrain. Platforms of interest are those of our vehicles weighing 40 tonnes and below. 
•	Signature Reduction - We are interested in solutions for reducing the visual, acoustic and electronic signatures of our vehicle fleet i.e. how easy it is for our vehicles to be seen, heard or sensed.
•	Weight saving - We are very interested to see solutions which demonstrate how technology could reduce the weight of our wheeled vehicles. Platform types of interest include all those vehicles weighing 20 tonnes and below e.g. Ridgeback, Jackal, Coyote, Husky, etc.
•	Stowage - We invite industry to demonstrate innovative solutions for optimising internal and external stowage across our entire vehicle fleet. Specific problems include: stowage of personal kit, stowage of individual weapons due to the lack of a universal weapon rack, external Stowage of fuel, Electronic Counter Measures and water (all of which will also require protection).

Technologies developed and equipment shall be evaluated and the performance and effectiveness demonstrated through the established MOD Level A-B-C trials process:
•	Level A – System Performance evaluation (paper assessment/system demonstration) 
•	Level B – Fight-ability (soldier field tests)/System performance capture 
•	Level C – User Performance & System Effectiveness (vignette trials) 

This MOD call for proposals will launch vis SBRI (The Technology Strategy Board) on Monday 16 September 2013 and will close on 23 October 2013 at 12:00 hrs. To register your interest in either of the two strands, go to www.innovateuk.org/competition-display-page/-/asset_publisher/RqEt2AKmEBhi/content/land-vehicle-exercise-lvex-2013

A Competition Brief and Statement of Work can be downloaded at the TSB portal above.
Application Process and supporting downloads
This competition is run by the Technology Strategy Board. All proposals must be submitted via the TSB Portal above.

Title: GB-swindon: The design, supply, delivery, and installation of laser safety equipment necessary to create a Laser Controlled Area (LCA)
Description:
1.	The Ministry of Defence (MoD) has a requirement for the design, supply, delivery, and installation of safety equipment necessary to create a Laser Controlled Area (LCA) within one of the laboratory spaces used by the Nuclear Department. 

2.	The Nuclear Department owns a Class 4 Laser which can be used to image water flowing in an acrylic channel. The laser will be operated in the ND Irradiation Facility in a room which is shared with other scientific equipment. To allow simultaneous use of the facility, which is a requirement, a Laser Controlled Area must be established in accordance with JSP 390 – Military Laser Safety.   As this system will be operated in a laboratory environment, the most relevant section is JSP 390 Volume 1 Issue 3 Section 3.

3.	The expected engineered solution is described in paragraph 4 however, other solutions that satisfy the requirements will also be considered.

4.	It is expected that the most cost effective way to establish the LCA is to divide the room into two areas using a laser blocking material which must comply with IEC 60825-4:2006 in the pitched roof space and a curtain, complying to the same specification, hanging below the trusses. The curtain is to be attached at each end to walls by an interlocked connection. Above the curtain, a laser blocking material must be used to fill the spaces between trusses which support the roof. A new interlock system is also required to replace the existing obsolete system.  The new system should allow for a short, timed,  interlock override to allow safe ingress/egress from the area while the laser is functioning (often the laser will need to run continuously for hours at a time to generate data).  In addition, the new interlock should be connected to external signs which indicate the state of the laser to anyone outside the laser controlled area.  Personal Protective Equipment (Eyewear) is also required for 5 people (based on the instructor plus 4 students). 

5.	The MoD will require a full description and “rough” drawing to be submitted at the tender stage to identify the proposed solution and safety functionality.

6.	The Authority envisages a need for a brief site survey to enable potential suppliers to inspect the facility and compile accurate measurements of the installation site. This is planned to take place on 15 Feb 16 13:30.

7.	The Authority has the desire for delivery and installation by the end of Mar 2016

Full details of the requirements for the Supply, Delivery and Installation of Safety Equipment for a Laser Controlled Area (LCA) will be included in the tender documents.

Please note it is MOD policy to make payment via Purchase to Payment (P2P).

Title: Provision of Emergency Driver Training
Description:
The University of Cumbria has been actively developing students to HCPC registration as paramedics for a number of years. We are currently developing a cohort of ten (10) Royal Air Force Combat Medical Technicians who will qualify as paramedics in December 2016. Title: Character Education Grant 2016-17
Description:
Please note that this is a grant.

Building on the success of the 2015-16 Character Education Grants, we are making grant funding available for the 2016-17 academic year to develop new approaches or expand and evaluate existing approaches that will support children and young people to be well-rounded, confident, happy and resilient – prepared for success in adult life.  

A total of £6m is available.  The successful bidders will deliver a programme to increase the number of young people involved in activities and environments that promote character education. The projects that we fund will aim to develop key character traits, attributes and behaviours in children aged 5-16 that support academic attainment; are valued by employers, and enable children to make a positive contribution to British society. 

As part of this programme, we will also fund projects that employ a military ethos approach to developing character.

Bids should include a clear plan and evidence base for how the above aims will be achieved. Applications will be assessed and prioritised according to the extent to which they meet the assessment criteria described in the application form.

Title: CB/BFG/0108 Provision of Bulk Fuel Carrying Vehicle Testing, Certification & Repair British Forces Germany
Description: Provision of Bulk Fuel Carrying Vehicle Testing, Certification & Repair of fuel dispensing/fluid systems fitted to British Forces Germany military vehicles.  The ADR (Accord European Relatif au Transport International du Merchandis Dangereuses par Route (European Agreement Concerning the International Carriage of Dangerous Goods by Road)) requires Fuel Vehicles to be subjected to elapsed time Intermediate (Leakproof) and Periodic (Hydraulic) examinations.  These are to be conducted by Examination Bodies accredited by the Competent Body of the EU country in which the vehicle or equipment is operating (in this instance, TüV Germany).  In addition to the periodic testing it also defines the requirement and safety precautions for gas freeing, tank cleaning, changing of grade/product and fuel vehicle tank repair.  Compliance with the European Regulations is mandated for the operation of all Ministry Of Defence fuel carrying vehicles.

Title: Commercial Resourcing Partner
Description:
The UK MOD’s Defence Equipment and Support (DE&S) is notifying the market of a potential forthcoming procurement to appoint a Commercial Resourcing Solution partner to provide personnel resources to work within the business across a range of different commercial delivery experiences and expertise.  

DE&S performs a vital, bespoke and challenging role in support of national security: it equips and supports the UK’s Armed Forces for operations now and in the future.  In procuring new military equipment, commodities and services, supporting in-service equipment through-life and managing global logistics operations, DE&S is responsible for delivering some of the most complex products and services in the world which covers around £14bn per annum of the MOD’s total third party spend with industry.  The bulk of the workforce however, is located on several main operating sites, with over half based at the main acquisition hub at Abbey Wood, Bristol.

Title: Provision of Support to RN Oceanographic Equipment
Description: There is a requirement for all Hydrographic Surveying capability to conform to Navy and International standards for accuracy. The operational effectiveness of the Navy’s Multi Beam Echo Sounder (MBES) is dependent on the accurate  measurement of a body of waters sound velocity profile and height of tide. In creation of navigational charts, the surveyor is required to gather information on tidal stream and seabed geo physics. To support military operations the HM branch gathers information on sound velocity and water visibility. To achieve the objective hydrographic units deploy a number of hull mounted, winch deployed, seabed mounted, towed and autonomous oceanographic sensors. These sensors require servicing to replace defective or wearing parts, corrosion protection and calibration on a regular basis.

Description:
Wear Debris Management System This is a Windows forms application which is used to support the end to end Wear Debris Analysis (WDA) process, as applied to military aircraft. WDMS supports the registration of samples, the recording of analysis results and the dissemination of advice and recommendations relating to air safety and the continuing airworthiness of aircraft subject to monitoring.

The information collected is used for reviewing aircraft engine and transmission systems with a view to monitoring fault trends and improving system reliability.

Title: For the Provision of Personal Support and Social Work Services to the United Kindom (UK) Royal Air Force (RAF)
Description:
It is United Kingdom (UK) Ministry of Defence (MOD) Royal Air Force (RAF) policy to provide a range of welfare support services to the RAF community in the UK. The MOD’s definition of Welfare is: ‘The provision of a widely recognised and accessible personal and community support structure that secures and improves the well-being of serving personnel and the Service community, is capable of adapting to societal, legislative and operational change and, in so doing, optimises the military capability and motivation of all Service men and women.’ 
RAF personnel and their families tend to lead a more mobile lifestyle than the civilian population, being posted to a different location every few years and often living in relatively remote areas. Mobility and the isolation of some units can separate RAF personnel and their families from their own extended family support mechanism. Moreover, Service families become separated from time to time, for periods of 6 months or more, when the Serving person is deployed abroad on operations or exercises. 

To take account of these factors, the RAF would like to continue to offer a contracted non-statutory Personal Support Service to the RAF Community that compliments other welfare support provided by the MOD, the RAF and Local Authority Statutory Agencies. This Advert is to seek interest from Industry for the provision of an output based non-statutory personal support and social work service to circa 32,000 RAF personnel, Regular and Reserves assigned to RAF administered units in the UK, as well as their families (spouses/civil partners and eligible children) in accordance with the contract Statement of Requirement. This will include the provision of confidential welfare support to Serving personnel and their families and specialist advice to unit staffs and station welfare casework committee meetings. The contract will be for five core years commencing 01 April 2017 to 31 March 2022, with a further two option years covering 01 April 2022 to 31 March 2023 and 01 April 2023 to 31 March 2024. Separate from the main requirement, the MOD (the Authority) wishes to preserve an option to consider a possible additional service of local Welfare Advisors to deliver practical and emotional support and welfare intervention activities to circa 1700 Service personnel undergoing training in Phase 1 and Phase 2 RAF administered training establishments.

Title: CCCC16A40 - Provision of Finance Systems Future Strategy Workshops
Description:
The MoD has a significant Oracle footprint e.g. throughout Finance, Military and Civilian Personnel systems. This has been implemented organically over a number of years through a series of incremental, mainly stand alone, projects. This has led to a footprint that is segmented over several sets of hardware, which means that business process flows are inherently dependent upon a large amount of interfaces which impact the smooth flow of data through the system and add unnecessary complexity.

The approach taken to date meets business requirements, though as the eBusiness Suite (eBS) is spread across disparate servers there has been limited ability to utilise the Commercial off the Shelf (CotS) workflow through the integration of eBS. The net result of the current deployed architecture is that there are inefficiencies in the use of applications and therefore in business process.

The release 2 of Contracting Purchasing and Finance (CP&F) on 20th October 2016 will span the Finance and Procurement applications estate. This will create opportunities, both to improve Business Process flows through CotS workflow and also System Data flows through CotS integration. Please note that HR and Payroll will remain on their own hardware and continue to provide finance related transactions (e.g. accounting impact of staff costs) to the DFMS.

The Planning, Budget and Forecasting (PB&F) process is mainly supported by Enterprise Planning, COGNOS functionality. The PB&F application is large and complex, and there are many “off-system” processes (e.g. Excel), that support the application. In addition the business process that PB&F supports is complex with many hand-offs between Head Office, and other MoD Departments. This in turn compounds the issues created by an over complex application. 
Director General Finance has established a Finance Transformation Programme to review the existing finance business processes and identify improvements. The Financial Management Strategy aligns to industry best practise that the Department should seek to continually improve the finance systems in incremental steps to deliver the improvements in the business process flows.

Title: The repair of High Pressure Pure Air Systems as fitted to Challenger 2
Description:
The Repair of the High Pressure Pure Air Systems as fitted to the Challenger 2 Platform. The authority reserves the right to include other military platforms during the lifetime of the contract.

Title: DE-BIELEFELD: CB/BFG/0120 - Supply of Industrial Gases to BFG
Description:
British Forces Germany (BFG) require a range of gaseous products to set specifications, over a 3 year period on a call-off basis,  to be supplied in Provider-owned cylinders leased to the Authority. The Provider will be required to deliver and collect cylinders to/from British military barracks within North-Rhine-Westphalia and centred on Paderborn, Bielefeld, Gütersloh and Sennelager. Delivery of cylinders when ordered will be required within one working week. The method of payment will be the Authority’s electronic Purchase to Payment system.  Cylinders required are anticipated as follows, but usage is not guaranteed, nor is this list exhaustive:

Title: GB-swindon: The design, supply, delivery, and installation of laser safety equipment necessary to create a Laser Controlled Area (LCA)
Description:
1.	The Ministry of Defence (MoD) has a requirement for the design, supply, delivery, and installation of safety equipment necessary to create a Laser Controlled Area (LCA) within one of the laboratory spaces used by the Nuclear Department. 

2.	The Nuclear Department owns a Class 4 Laser which can be used to image water flowing in an acrylic channel. The laser will be operated in the ND Irradiation Facility in a room which is shared with other scientific equipment. To allow simultaneous use of the facility, which is a requirement, a Laser Controlled Area must be established in accordance with JSP 390 – Military Laser Safety.   As this system will be operated in a laboratory environment, the most relevant section is JSP 390 Volume 1 Issue 3 Section 3.

3.	The expected engineered solution is described in paragraph 4 however, other solutions that satisfy the requirements will also be considered.

4.	It is expected that the most cost effective way to establish the LCA is to divide the room into two areas using a laser blocking material which must comply with IEC 60825-4:2006 in the pitched roof space and a curtain, complying to the same specification, hanging below the trusses. The curtain is to be attached at each end to walls by an interlocked connection. Above the curtain, a laser blocking material must be used to fill the spaces between trusses which support the roof. A new interlock system is also required to replace the existing obsolete system.  The new system should allow for a short, timed,  interlock override to allow safe ingress/egress from the area while the laser is functioning (often the laser will need to run continuously for hours at a time to generate data).  In addition, the new interlock should be connected to external signs which indicate the state of the laser to anyone outside the laser controlled area.  Personal Protective Equipment (Eyewear) is also required for 5 people (based on the instructor plus 4 students). 

5.	The MoD will require a full description and “rough” drawing to be submitted at the tender stage to identify the proposed solution and safety functionality.

6.	The Authority envisages a need for a brief site survey to enable potential suppliers to inspect the facility and compile accurate measurements of the installation site. This is planned to take place on 15 Feb 16 13:30.

7.	The Authority has the desire for delivery and installation by the end of Mar 2016

Full details of the requirements for the Supply, Delivery and Installation of Safety Equipment for a Laser Controlled Area (LCA) will be included in the tender documents.

Please note it is MOD policy to make payment via Purchase to Payment (P2P).

orgName: N E L Commissioning Support Unit
Title: RTL055P - Veterans' Mental Health Services (2017)
Description:
RTL055P - Veterans' Mental Health Services 2017 
Following the publication of the engagement work in relation to veterans mental health services NHS England is looking to secure providers to deliver a comprehensive veterans’ mental health service across England from April 2017. 

The Transition, intervention and liaison service for veterans will offer: 

• A service for those in transition – offering assessment and therapeutic mental health services for those who are in the process of leaving the armed forces; 
• A service for veterans with complex presentations – offering case management, co-ordination and care for those veterans with complex presentations including those who have suffered significant psychological trauma where a military understanding would be beneficial; 
• A general service for veterans - offering navigation and liaison support to other services to ensure that veterans receive appropriate care. 
Providers must be capable of delivering the service across a wide geography which may include through a lead or prime contractor model. 
Providers must also demonstrate how they will link with appropriate and relevant third sector organisations to ensure that the needs of veterans are met. 
This procurement is split into 4 (four) geographical Lots. 
Lot 1 - North
Lot 2 - Midlands & East
Lot 3 - South East & London
Lot 4 - South Central & South West

NHS England will seek to award one contract for each of the tender Lots.

Bidders are able to bid for any number or combination of the Lots. However, following ITT evaluation, NHS England will not award any Bidder more than one Lot.

The contract duration is an initial period of 36 months (3 years) followed by an option extension of a further 24 months (2 years). Therefore the full, extended, duration of the contracts will be a maximum of 60 months (5 years).

The contract values vary per Lot. See documentation for details. The higher value in this advert relates to the full extended contract value of all 4 Lots combined (Ex VAT).

See procurement documentation (PQQ) for more details. 

Interested Bidders must access the PQQ documentation via the link provided and submit a PQQ response via the online questionnaire on the e-Tendering portal "ProContract" before the submission deadline of 4th November 2016 at 12:00 (noon).

NHS England will adopt the Restricted procedure as a template for this procurement. However, the Services to which this PQQ relates fall within Schedule 3 to the Public Contracts Regulations 2015 (the Regulations).  Neither the publication of the advertisement, the use of a PQQ stage, nor the use of the term “Restricted Procedure” nor any other indication (including any statement in this advert or the PQQ documentation) shall be taken to mean that the Authority intends to hold itself bound by any of the Regulations, save those applicable to procurements under the Light Touch Regime (LTR).
Additional Text:
If you are not already registered on the portal you will need to register. Guidance on how to register is attached. Once registered, you will need to navigate to "Current Opportunities". Within this area there is a project called “RTL055P Veterans Mental Health Services (2017)”. Click the link for the opportunity (shown in the "Links" section of this advert) and in the right hand box on the screen titled: “Expression of Interest Window”, please log-in and register your interest in this opportunity. Follow the instructions to express an interest. You should then receive two emails; 1: advising that you have successfully registered your interest, 2: advising you that the documents are now available to download. You will then need to use the portal to access and download the PQQ documentation. Please note that by expressing an interest you are NOT committing yourself to submit a bid. Please see Pro-Contract "Help" attachment for further information and instructions on expressing an interest, navigating to the PQQ stage of the portal to access the documentation and submitting a questionnaire response.

Questions should be directed via the messaging facility on the portal in the first instance.

orgName: Ministry of Defence, Defence Medical Services
Title: GB-Lichfield: The Provision of Orthodontic Consultant Cover
Description:
Defence Primary Healthcare require a Defence Consultant Advisory Service to work in our secondary care referral centre based in Aldershot. The role requires working as part of a successful team who provide a comprehensive range of multi-disciplinary treatment options for the rehabilitation of service personnel.
 
Clinician required one morning session 0800-1230 per calendar month (date by mutual agreement) for treatment planning in conjunction with our full time restorative and visiting maxillofacial consultants and to oversee orthodontic treatment carried out by MOrth qualified specialist clinicians.  

Our orthodontists currently utilise MBT mechanics and are supported by high quality in house technicians. We have a high throughput of adult multidisciplinary patients from across the Royal Navy, Army and Air Force along with the children of those who serve overseas have treatment planned and co-ordinated from the central Aldershot hub, with the occasional use of videoconferencing to provide advice to remote locations.     

All applicants must hold an in date DBS certificate, pass the MOD security clearance checks, hold appropriate indemnity insurance, meet all appropriate occupational health requirements and hold a current NHS orthodontic consultant contract. Comprehensive induction package to enable effective work within the military environment, this will not involve any physical activity.

The term of the contract is for an initial 3 year period with an optional, up to, 24 month extension.

Estimated total value excluding VAT: 6,000 GBP per annum.

The Award Criteria is set out within the procurement documents.

Title: Coaching/Flight Simulator
Description: This contract has been awarded and this notice is being published for transparency purposes.  As part of UK Sport’s Coaching Programme (information about which can be found on: http://www.uksport.gov.uk/our-work/coaching ) approximately for the period from August 2016 to March 2019 UK Sport is inviting expressions of interest regarding a flight simulation to improve human performance. The purpose of a flight simulation activity would be to enhance the individual’s self-awareness, develop decision making and to evolve communication techniques all whilst experiencing a large cognitive load combined with a high pressure environment. This would look to be done through a team undertaking the flight simulation to examine themselves and the broader efficiency as a unit with the information gathered to then be built back into their working environments. This would ideally be situated within reasonable travel distance to the UK Sport head office in central London. In order to maximise the learning and development of attendees it is anticipated that the supplier be able to display skills and expertise relating to: • Aviation • Human Performance • Flight Training • Military Background • Commercial flying background • Business Leadership and Team Development Suppliers should note that UK Sport is currently in the formative stages of developing its requirements for this service.
Additional Text: Please note this contract has been awarded and this notice is being published for transparency purposes.

Title: New Website Design and Implementation for Richmondshire District Council
Description: Richmondshire District Council wants to build a new, more modern website that will suit the needs of all its customers whilst also due to reductions in funding has been looking at its services to identify the efficiency savings required. As part of this programme, it has become apparent that the website could be better used - to improve the interaction between the council and its residents, visitors and businesses, as well as to improve the adherence to legal regulations. The Richmondshire district covers 509 square miles of North Yorkshire - one of the most sparsely populated district council areas in the country with its boundaries stretching from the River Tees to Cumbria. The area is predominantly rural in character and a large part is situated in the Yorkshire Dales National Park. Richmond is the largest town in the district with its Norman Castle, cobbled marketplace, famous Georgian Theatre Royal and elegant Georgian buildings. The district also boasts two other bustling market towns - Leyburn and Hawes, and many urban developments to the east - Catterick, Scotton, Hipswell, Colburn and Brompton on Swale. Reeth is also a service centre for the Upper Dales. Two main arterial roads - the A1 North/South and the A66 East/West five miles from Richmond - give easy nationwide access. Employment opportunities are good with light industry within and close to the district. It also contains the largest military establishment in the country, Catterick Garrison, which adds greatly to the economic wellbeing of the area. The area boasts good schools and health facilities and a range of excellent housing. The existing website richmondshire.gov.uk was developed almost three years ago and though it has served its purpose well it is now deemed to be out of date and have insufficient functionality. The domain name is owned by Richmondshire District Council. Internal research has shown that sections and customers would welcome improved functionality such as payment tools and interactive mapping systems from a new website. An intuitive content management system would assist in improving the customer experience when dealing with the council through the website. Richimondshire District Council are advertising this tender via YORtender and would require prospective supplier to submit any tenders via this portal. The contract will be initially for 3 years with an optional 2 x 12 months' extension at the Councils discretion.

orgName: Ministry of Defence, Land Equipment, Other
Title: Challenger 2 Life Extension Project
Description:
For the avoidance of doubt, this Contract Notice and Dynamic Pre-Qualification Questionnaire (DPQQ) are being released in advance of a formal approval of available funding to initiate a competition. This approach is intended to accelerate the subsequent release of an Invitation to Negotiate (ITN) to the pre-selected field of bidders once approval to proceed to competition has been confirmed. For planning purposes only the Authority is assuming that formal approval will be achieved in late January 2016.
      
      The UK Ministry of Defence (MOD) Armoured Vehicles Programmes (The Authority) has a possible future requirement to deliver a Challenger 2 Life Extension Project (CR2 LEP). The user requires the CR2 Main Battle Tank (MBT) Out of Service Date to be extended from 2025 to 2035, in order to continue to provide precision direct fire manoeuvre capability across a broad spectrum of operations. CR2 LEP seeks to address obsolescence issues to maintain main battle tank capability until 2035. This is a Category A Military Project (up to £700M inclusive of VAT, including initial logistic support).
      
      Subject to internal approvals, the Authority intends to conduct a Competitive Negotiated Competition under the Defence Security and Public Contracts Regulations 2011 with the intention of inviting a minimum of three tenderers. From these tenders the Authority intends to utilise Most Economically Advantageous Tender (MEAT) principles to down select to two Prime Contractors, with each being invited to independently undertake a 2 year Assessment Phase (AP) under contracts not to exceed the Authority's total AP budget of £42M inclusive of UK VAT. The ultimate aim of the competition will be to award a Demonstration, Manufacture and In-service Support (DMI) contract to the bidder which at the conclusion of the AP provides the most economically advantageous tender for the DMI contract.   
      
      During the AP the Authority will negotiate with the AP contractors under the Competitive Negotiated Procedure to refine their specific DMI proposals which will be evaluated at the conclusion of the AP. The Authority will then select a winner who, subject to a Main Gate investment decision, will deliver their proposed DMI solution in accordance with the terms included in the ITN and resolved during the AP. The ultimately successful DMI contractor will be required to formally undertake the role of Design Authority (DA) for the whole Platform. The timing for establishing formal DA status would be co-incident with the successful achievement of Critical Design Review during the D&M Phase.  
      
      Industry should note that the Invitation To Negotiate (ITN) will require the AP contractors to consider support options for any new to service items in conjunction with the Authority's primary Support provider (Babcock DSG Ltd), which is the existing provider of support to the Platform (and its common based platform variants) via existing Inventory and Repair Contracts. AP bidders will be expecte

Title: The Provision of Academic Support to the Royal College of Defence Studies
Description: The Provision of Academic Support to the Royal College of Defence Studies (RCDS) requirement will support a 3 x eleven-month courses at post-graduate level in international strategic studies with the possibility of a further, single option year.  It focuses on security, stability and prosperity at the grand strategic level of governmental decisions, both nationally and within the international community.  The course follows the academic year, running from September to July.  The Members  (as students are called), predominantly but not only from military backgrounds, represent a broad experience base and are selected for their potential to reach the highest ranks of senior leadership and advisory posts in their own countries.  The focus of study on the course is practical rather than theoretical.
Additional Text:

DPQQs should be submitted by 22/02/2017.

Title: DE-BIELEFELD: CB/BFG/0120 - Supply of Industrial Gases to BFG
Description:
British Forces Germany (BFG) require a range of gaseous products to set specifications, over a 3 year period on a call-off basis,  to be supplied in Provider-owned cylinders leased to the Authority. The Provider will be required to deliver and collect cylinders to/from British military barracks within North-Rhine-Westphalia and centred on Paderborn, Bielefeld, Gütersloh and Sennelager. Delivery of cylinders when ordered will be required within one working week. The method of payment will be the Authority's electronic Purchase to Payment system.  Cylinders required are anticipated as follows, but usage is not guaranteed, nor is this list exhaustive:
      
      1	 Oxygen  - water capacity per litre - 10 - estimated usage per annum -  2
      2	 Oxygen  - water capacity per litre - 20 - estimated usage per annum -  1
      3	 Oxygen  - water capacity per litre - 50 - estimated usage per annum -  25
      4	 Nitrogen - water capacity per litre - 10 - estimated usage per annum -  2
      5	 Nitrogen - water capacity per litre - 20 - estimated usage per annum -  4
      6	 Nitrogen - water capacity per litre - 50 - estimated usage per annum -  12
      7	 Compressed air EN 12021 - water capacity per litre - 50 - estimated usage per annum -  4
      8	 Compressed air  - water capacity per litre - 10 - estimated usage per annum -  1
      9	 Argon  - water capacity per litre - 10 - estimated usage per annum -  8
      10	 Argon  - water capacity per litre - 20 - estimated usage per annum -  2
      11	 Argon  - water capacity per litre - 50 - estimated usage per annum -  4
      12	 5% C02, 4% 02/Ar  - water capacity per litre - 50 - estimated usage per annum -  2
      13	 5% C02, 4% 02/Ar  - water capacity per litre - 10 - estimated usage per annum -  2
      14	 5% C02, 4% 02/Ar  - water capacity per litre - 20 - estimated usage per annum -  12
      15	 5% C02, 4% 02/Ar  - water capacity per litre - 50 - estimated usage per annum -  6
      16	 Acetylene  - water capacity per litre - 20 estimated usage per annum -  1
      17	 Acetylene  - water capacity per litre - 48 - estimated usage per annum -  16
      18	 Propane (liquid gas)  - water capacity per litre - 33 - estimated usage per annum -  1
      19	 Carbon dioxide   - water capacity per litre - 13 - estimated usage per annum -  2
      20	 Carbon dioxide  - water capacity per litre - 20 - estimated usage per annum -  6
      
      The Contract Award criteria will be based on the lowest priced commercially and technically compliant bid with price judged by cylinder, rent per day, delivery and any other attributable charges, across the above range of gaseous products based on estimated annual usage. This is a sample only, for evaluation purposes and it is not to be assumed that the Authority would order this exact volume. Any questions which are indicated as Mandatory in the subsequent Tender documentation and are answered 'NO' will be deemed as technically non-compliant and therefore unacceptable.

Title: The Supply of Airworthiness Medical Equipment Testing
Description:
The requirement is for the provision of a call-off contract to enable items of medical equipment to be
assessed that they are safe to use on-board military aircraft and that it conforms to airworthiness and safety
requirements, Electromagnetic Magnetic Compatibility (EMC) & Environmental Testing, along with an
assessment of compliance against the 'Generic Specification for Special Purpose Aeromedical Equipment',
which will be provided by Leidos. The provider of the service hereafter known as the "Commodity
Supplier" will deliver written reports to provide documentary evidence to Air Platform Teams and Release
to Service Authority (RTSA's).

Title: EA to Conduct Preferred Choice Modelling Analysis for Armed Forces People Programme
Description:
Requirement - The Armed Forces People Programme requires "stated preference" modelling to understand the likely impact on recruiting and retention of Service (military) personnel of a number of options for a new package of financial and non-financial rewards (the "New Offer"), and of new contract terms that will allow Service Personnel to work part-time or to limit their liability to be moved around the country or overseas.
Background - The United Kingdom's 2015 Strategic Defence and Security Review (SDSR) undertook to "enable our Armed Forces to work more flexibly, reflecting the realities of modern life"  and to "develop a new Armed Forces offer for new joiners".  The Armed Forces People Programme's mission is to deliver the commitments made in SDSR. Its vision is to create "a modern and inclusive Armed Forces which attracts, retains and values its people, in order to enhance operational capability, offering choice as to how they live and work, and providing a comprehensive and sustainable reward package that recognises their commitment and service."
Additional Text: Please Note: This tender process is complete and contract has been awarded.

Title: GB-Salisbury: BDF Phase 2
Description:
Research towards a biosurveillance (BSV) system, is required by MoD. It will aim to provide early warning, situational awareness and forecasting of disease activity in an operational context. Outbreaks may be caused by naturally occurring infections, accidental contamination or deliberate biological attacks. A BSV capability will need to fuse data from disparate military and civilian sources, to provide decision-makers with a comprehensive daily picture of disease activity within an Area of Interest (AOI).
      
      The aim of this work is to further develop and demonstrate a working prototype BSV data fusion method, utilising simulated data based on currently available data sources, and provide Open Source code for the data fusion with documentation commensurate with Technical Readiness Level (TRL) 3.

orgName: Ministry of Defence, C&C, HMNB Portsmouth
Title: GB-Gosport: Noise and Vibration measuring equipment required for INM's Accoustic & Vibration Department.
Description:
Noise and Vibration measuring equipment required for INM's Accoustic & Vibration Department. 
      
      There is a need for a dedicated computer-based data acquisition measurement system for noise and vibration for use in the different military platforms.  The general and detailed specifications for the system are as follows:
      
      	It must be a Multi-channel data acquisition system.
      	It must be able to stream data simultaneously for a minimum of 6 channels.
      	It must have a sample and hold facility during data acquisition.
      	It must be able to acquire data up to a frequency of 50,000 Hz.
      	It must have flexibility on the type of input transducer that can be used.
      	It must be able to accept a current microphones and accelerometers.
      	The complete system must be portable.
      	It should include self-powered ability for remote environments (battery powered).
      	It should have wireless operation ability for use in harsh environments.
      	It should be expandable to include more channels in the future.
      	It should have a remote control unit for real-time checking of data.
      	The software should be compatible with formats within the section (e.g. WAV files).
      	It should have the ability to acquire large amounts of data (~60 Gb).
Additional Text:
To view this notice, register as a supplier here:
        
        http://www.contracts.mod.uk/delta/signup.html?userType=supplier
        
        and search for the notice with reference 'GB-Gosport: Noise and Vibration measuring equipment required for INM's Accoustic & Vibration Department.'.

Title: For Transparency Purposes Only - Provision of Accreditation for Artificer Training at MOD Lyneham for the Period 1 April 2017 to 31 March 2020 with a Further Option Period of up to 2 Years
Description:
Education and training services. The role of the Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers (REME) is to support equipment capability
in the Army and REME artificers play a key role in delivering day-to-day support to the Army's equipment fleets, both in barracks and, critically, on operations. In addition, REME
artificers are employed in planning posts aimed at improving both equipment capability and
availability to the User.
The Authority requires a single Higher Education (HE) provider to accredit the Electronic,
Avionic & Aircraft REME Artificer Training Streams to the industry standard, with named
pathways for each of the 3 engineering disciplines. The new accrediting body will be required
to review course content, teaching processes, validation, Accreditation of Prior Learning (APL) and Accreditation of Prior Experiential Learning (APEL). The resultant accreditation
is desired to achieve a level similar to that currently awarded in science or engineering although, as a minimum requirement, a Level 5 qualification to Foundation Degree must be realised. Ultimately it must allow all Artificers to be able to apply for professional
registration as Incorporated Engineers with the Engineering Council. The full accreditation
must be in place by no later than 1 April 2017 in orders to provide the resultant single award
to Artificers on completion of their Artificer course which is likely to be 18 - 21 months later.
The HE Provider must be capable of working with the School staff; a mixture of military,
civil servant and MOD Contractors and be flexible enough to deal with the way in which the training is already being delivered. The Site for the delivery of all services is DSEME, MOD
Lyneham. DSEME, MOD Lyneham is sited at The Prince Phillip Barracks, MOD Lyneham,
Wiltshire, SN15 4XX.
Contact Address 1: 3 Site, Nimrod Building, Royal Air Force

Notice Identifier: CCIH17B37 (RCA120113) Provision of Hardware for NATO Federated Mission Network (FMN)
Title: Provision of Hardware for NATO Federated Mission Network (FMN)
Description:
Please note that this notice is for transparency purposes only. 
Joint Forces Command (JFC) were inviting bids for the Provision of Hardware for the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) Federated Mission Network (FMN). JFC may be referred to as the ''Authority'' hereafter. JFC is part of the Ministry of Defence (MOD).
The Authority has a requirement to field a NATO FMN compliant Operational Computer Information System (OpCIS) capability.
This requirement is to stand up Hosting Environments, Network Interconnection Points, and a Demilitarized Zone (DMZ). This is in support of enhanced NATO Reaction Force (eNRF) very high readiness tasks, capable of being secured to Military Hardening Standards.
The requirement is solely for the provision of all of the hardware, no installation / configuration was required for the hardware. The Authority required warranty and three (3) year support for some of the hardware outlined. The Authority's requirement was for the infrastructure needed to build: 
2 x Mission Network Elements (MNE's) and; 
2 x Mission Network Extensions (MNX's).

orgName: Ministry of Defence, Land Equipment, Operational Infrastructure Programme (OIP)
Title: Project TYRO - General Support Bridge
Description:
Short description of the nature and scope of works or nature and quantity or value of supplies and services
      
      1. Mobile bridges
      
      1.1 The Departments Operational Infrastructure (OI) team has identified a possible future requirement for the Heavy Forces General Support Bridging (GSB) capability to support UK forces out to 2040. The GSB system is used within the indirect fire zone. The new capability shall have a minimum Military Load Classification (MLC) of 100 Tracked.
      
      2. Contract Type
      
      2.1 A single contract to cover Demonstration, Manufacture and In Service Support for the GSB bridging system.
      
      2.2. The competition will run simultaneously with Close Support Bridge (CSB) and in the event of a single Potential Provider being identified for both systems, a single contract may be awarded for both systems.
      
      3. Potential options to satisfy the capability requirements include but not limited to;
      
      3.1. An existing Commercial Off The Shelf system; or
      
      3.2. A Modified Off The Shelf system; or
      
      3.3. A system under development that shall be available for delivery for use on training, exercises and operations no later than the end 2021.
      
      4. The Authority Requires
      
      4.1. The system shall be suitably demonstrated against the contract requirements.
      
      4.2. That you would take Design Authority (DA) responsibility for the system you deliver should the system be taken forward to the manufacture phase.
      
      4.3. A system comprising approximately 13 - 21 sets which are capable of spanning a gap of at least 30m and is scalable to span a gap of at least 60m with the use of additional equipment whilst maintaining the minimum MLC. The system also includes a wheeled launch/recovery vehicle and wheeled support vehicles (vehicles/trailers) to transport bridging components.
      
      4.4 A support solution from delivery of first bridging set with potential options through the equipment life out to 2040.
      
      4.5 As part of this requirement, the Authority may consider inclusion of  'Whole Force Approach' in the equipment support solution.
Additional Text:
To view this notice, register as a supplier here:
        
        http://www.contracts.mod.uk/delta/signup.html?userType=supplier
        
        and search for the notice with reference 'UK-Bristol: Mobile bridges.'.

orgName: Ministry of Defence, Land Equipment, Operational Infrastructure Programme (OIP)
Title: Project TYRO - Close Support Bridge
Description:
Short description of the nature and scope of works or nature and quantity or value of supplies and services
      
      1. Mobile bridges
      
      1.1 The Departments Operational Infrastructure (OI) team has identified a possible future requirement for Heavy Forces Close Support Bridging (CSB) capability to support UK forces out to 2040. The CSB system is used within the direct fire zone (and dependant on TITAN Armoured Vehicle Launder Bridge (AVLB). The capability shall have a minimum Military Load Classification (MLC) of 100 Tracked.
      
      2. Contract Type
      
      2.1 A single contract to cover Demonstration, Manufacture and In Service Support for the CSB bridging system.
      
      2.2. The competition will run simultaneously with General Support Bridge (GSB) and in the event of a single Potential Provider being identified for both systems, a single contract may be awarded for both systems.
      
      3. Potential options to satisfy the capability requirements include but not limited to;
      
      3.1. An existing Commercial Off The Shelf system; or
      
      3.2. A Modified Off The Shelf system; or
      
      3.3. A system under development that shall be available for delivery for use on training, exercises and operations no later than the end 2021.
      
      4. The Authority Requires
      
      4.1. The system shall be suitably demonstrated against the contract requirements.
      
      4.2. That you would take Design Authority (DA) responsibility for the system you deliver should the system be taken forward to the manufacture phase.
      
      4.3. A system comprising approximately 25 - 35 sets which are rapidly launched/recovered by the TITAN Armoured Vehicle Launch Bridge (AVLB) with each set consisting of 2 x short bridge capable of spanning a gap of at least 11.5m and 1 x Medium Bridge capable of spanning a gap of at least 24.5m and is scalable to span a gap of at least 60m with the use of additional equipment whilst maintaining the minimum MLC. The system also includes a wheeled launch/recovery vehicle and wheeled support vehicles (vehicles/trailers) to transport bridging components.
      
      
      4.4 A support solution from delivery of first bridging set with potential options through the equipment life out to 2040.
      
      4.5 As part of this requirement, the Authority may consider inclusion of 'Whole Force Approach' in the equipment support solution.

Title: GB-GLASGOW: HOCS3b/00055 - Provision of DDC News Press Management System
Description:
1.	Directorate of Defence Communications (DDC) is  the central communications directorate of the Ministry of Defence which provides policy and guidance on defence-wide media and communications. 
      The DDC News manages all media contact and currently has a requirement for an on-line database to log and manage media enquiries, collate interview requests for ministers and to forecast upcoming issues.
      
      The News Team within DDC operates a 24 hour a day service to domestic and international media 345 days a year. Each and every day the majority of the news team will interact with national, regional and trade journalists and are required to provide a timely and accurate service in order to fulfil the department's strategic communications objectives. 
      As one of the busiest communications teams in Whitehall, DDC News will issue numerous statements, provide guidance on a wide variety of subjects and will process interview bids for Ministers and senior members of the military every day. In order to do this it is imperative that there is a system in place that logs journalist interaction and provides a database for all statements that have been issued. This allows consistency in messaging and allows individual members of the News team who may not specialise in one subject area to access information and respond to enquiries quickly.
      
      The News Team currently uses a single word document to save all media statements and attempts to save core scripts on the shared MOSS site. This comes with limitations as a shared word document does not allow the news team to log individual contacts with journalists and, as lines evolve and change, it often causes confusion when trying to find statements devoid of background and context in a single word file.  
      Using a single word file has led to individual members of the News team trying to find statements that have been issued in previous media coverage rather than through our own systems. This is because the single word file for 2016 consisted of 600 pages making it very difficult for lines to be found. It is currently not uncommon for one member of the News team to have to phone the Communications Officer who dealt with original request for information to get clarity on the latest line to take and to get the background on an incoming media enquiry. This can often happen out of hours and during the night which is clearly not acceptable.
      Given the lack of certainly with previously issued statements, there is concern that an individual communications officer could unknowingly issue an out of date line or provide a journalist with incorrect information due to a lack of a central resource to log and store statements DDC is therefore seeking a new platform in which all media interaction can be logged..
Additional Text:
To view this notice, register as a supplier here:
        
        http://www.contracts.mod.uk/delta/signup.html?userType=supplier
        
        and search for the notice with reference 'GB-GLASGOW: HOCS3b/00055 - Provision of DDC News Press Management System'.
